SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter yong Bertram Count of Roſſillion, his Mother, and Helena, Lord Lafew, all in blacke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mother.
SPEECH.LINE: In deliuering my ſonne from me, I burie a ſe-
cond husband.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: And I in going Madam, weep ore my
fathers death anew; but I muſt attend his maie-
ſties command, to whom I am now in Ward, ouermore
in ſubieƈtion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: You ſhall find of the King a husband Madame,
you ſir a father. He that ſo generally is at all times good,
muſt of neceſſitie hold his vertue to you, whoſe worthi-
neſſe would ſtirre it vp where it wanted rather then lack
it where there is ſuch abundance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mo.
SPEECH.LINE: What hope is there of his Maieſties amendment?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: He hath abandon’d his Phiſitions Madam, vn-
der whoſe praƈtiſes he hath perſecuted time with hope,
and finds no other aduantage in the proceſſe, but onely
the looſing of hope by time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mo.
SPEECH.LINE: This yong Gentlewoman had a father, O that
had, how ſad a paſſage tis, whoſe skill was almoſt as
great as his honeſtie, had it ſtretch’d ſo far, would haue
made nature immortall, and death ſhould haue play for
lacke of worke. Would for the Kings ſake hee were li-
uing, I thinke it would be the death of the Kings diſeaſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: How call’d you the man you ſpeake of Madam?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mo.
SPEECH.LINE: He was famous ſir in his profeſſion, and it was
his great right to be ſo: Gerard de Narbon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: He was excellent indeed Madam, the King very
latelie ſpoke of him admiringly, and mourningly: hee
was skilfull enough to haue liu’d ſtil, if knowledge could
be ſet vp againſt mortallitie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: What is it (my good Lord) the King languiſhes
of?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: A Fiſtula my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: I heard not of it before.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: I would it were not notorious. Was this Gen-
tlewoman the Daughter of Gerard de Narbon?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mo.
SPEECH.LINE: His ſole childe my Lord, and bequeathed to my
ouer looking. I haue thoſe hopes of her good, that her
education promiſes her diſpoſitions ſhee inherits,
which makes faire gifts fairer: for where an vncleane mind car-
ries vertuous qualities, there commendations go with
pitty, they are vertues and traitors too: in her they are
the better for their ſimpleneſſe; ſhe deriues her honeſtie,
and atcheeues her goodneſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lafew.
SPEECH.LINE: Your commendations Madam get from her
teares.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mo.
SPEECH.LINE: ’Tis the beſt brine a Maiden can ſeaſon her praiſe
in. The remembrance of her father neuer approches her
heart, but the tirrany of her ſorrowes takes all liuelihood
from her cheeke. No more of this Helena, go too, no
more leaſt it be rather thought you affeƈt a ſorrow, then
to haue—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hell.
SPEECH.LINE: I dœ affeƈt a ſorrow indeed, but I haue it too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Moderate lamentation is the right of the dead,
exceſſiue greefe the enemie to the liuing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mo.
SPEECH.LINE: If the liuing be enemie to the greefe, the exceſſe
makes it ſoone mortall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Maddam I deſire your holie wiſhes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: How vnderſtand we that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mo.
SPEECH.LINE: Be thou bleſt Bertrame, and ſucceed thy father
In manners as in ſhape: thy blood and vertue
Contend for Empire in thee, and thy goodneſſe
Share with thy birth-right. Loue all, truſt a few,
Dœ wrong to none: be able for thine enemie
Rather in power then vſe: and keepe thy friend
Vnder thy owne lifes key. Be checkt for ſilence,
But neuer tax’d for ſpeech. What heauen more wil,
That thee may furniſh, and my prayers plucke downe,
Fall on thy head. Farwell my Lord,
’Tis an vnſeaſon’d Courtier, good my Lord
Aduiſe him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: He cannot want the beſt
That ſhall attend his loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mo.
SPEECH.LINE: Heauen bleſſe him: Farwell Bertram.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ro.
SPEECH.LINE: The beſt wiſhes that can be forg’d in your thoghts
be ſeruants to you: be comfortable to my mother, your
Miſtris, and make much of her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Farewell prettie Lady, you muſt hold the cre-
dit of your father.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hell.
SPEECH.LINE: O were that all, I thinke not on my father,
And theſe great teares grace his remembrance more
Then thoſe I ſhed for him. What was he like?
I haue forgott him. My imagination
Carries no fauour in’t but Bertrams.
I am vndone, there is no liuing, none,
If Bertram be away. ’Twere all one,
That I ſhould loue a bright particuler ſtarre,
And think to wed it, he is ſo aboue me
In his bright radience and colaterall light,
Muſt I be comforted, not in his ſphere;
Th’ ambition in my loue thus plagues it ſelfe:
The hind that would be mated by the Lion
Muſt die for loue. ’Twas prettie, though a plague
To ſee him euerie houre to ſit and draw
His arched browes, his hawking eie, his curles
In our hearts table: heart too capeable
Of euerie line and tricke of his ſweet fauour.
But now he's gone, and my idolatrous fancie
Muſt ſanƈtiﬁe his Reliques. Who comes heere?
One that goes with him: I loue him for his ſake,
And yet I know him a notorious Liar,
Thinke him a great way foole, ſolie a coward,
Yet theſe fixt euils ſit ſo fit in him,
That they take place, when Vertues ſteely bones
Lookes bleake i’th cold wind: withall, full oﬅe we ſee
Cold wiſedome waighting on ſuperﬂuous follie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Saue you faire Queene.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: And you Monarch.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: No.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: And no.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Are you meditating on virginitie?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: I: you haue ſome ſtaine of ſouldier in you: Let
mee aske you a queſtion. Man is enemie to virginitie,
how may we barracado it againſt him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Keepe him out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: But he aſſailes, and our virginitie though vali-
ant, in the defence yet is weak: vnfold to vs ſome war-
like reſiſtance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: There is none: Man ſetting downe before you,
will vndermine you, and blow you vp.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: Bleſſe our poore Virginity from vnderminers
and blowers vp. Is there no Military policy how Vir-
gins might blow vp men?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Virginity beeing blowne downe, Man will
quicklier be blowne vp: marry in blowing him downe
againe, with the breach your ſelues made, you loſe your
Citty. It is not politicke, in the Common-wealth of
Nature, to preſerue virginity. Loſſe of Virginitie, is
rationall encreaſe, and there was neuer Virgin gœ, till
virginitie was firſt loſt. That you were made of, is met-
tall to make Virgins. Virginitie, by beeing once loſt,
may be ten times found: by being euer kept, it is euer
loſt: ‘tis too cold a companion: Away with’t.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: I will ſtand for’t a little, though therefore I die
a Virgin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: There’s little can bee ſaide in’t, ’tis againſt the
rule of Nature. To ſpeake on the part of virginitie, is
to accuſe your Mothers; which is mo’t infallible diſo-
bedience. He that hangs himſelfe is a Virgin: Virgini-
tie murthers it ſelfe, and ſhould be buried in highwayes
out of all ſanƈtified limit, as a deſperate Offendreſſe a-
gainſt Nature. Virginitie breedes mites, much like a
Cheeſe, conſumes it ſelfe to the very payring, and ſo
dies with feeding his owne ſtomacke. Beſides, Virgini-
tie is peeuiſh, proud, ydle, made of ſelfe-loue, which
which is the moſt inhibited ſinne in the Cannon. Keepe it not,
you cannot chooſe but looſe by’t. Out with’t: within
ten yeare it will make it ſelfe two, which is a goodly in-
creaſe, and the principall it ſelfe not much the worſe.
Away with’t.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: How might one do ſir, to looſe it to her owne
liking?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Let mee ſee. Marry ill, to like him that ne’re
it likes. ’Tis a commodity wil lose the gloſſe with lying:
The longer kept, the leſſe worth: Off with’t while ’tis
vendible. Anſwer the time of requeſt, Virginitie like
an olde Courtier, weares her cap out of faſhion, richly
ſuted, but vnſuteable, iuſt like the brooch & the tooth-
pick, which were not now: your Date is better in your
Pye and your Porredge, then in your cheeke: and your
virginity, your old virginity, is like one of our French
wither’d peares, it lookes ill, it eates drily, marry ’tis a
wither’d peare: it was formerly better, marry yet ’tis a
wither’d peare: Will you any thing with it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: Not my virginity yet:
There ſhall your Maſter haue a thouſand loues,
A Mother, and a Miſtreſſe, and a friend,
A Phenix, Captaine, and an enemy,
A guide, a Goddeſſe, and a Soueraigne,
A Counſellor, a Traitoreſſe, and a Deare:
His humble ambition, proud humility:
His iarring, concord: and his diſcord, dulcet:
His faith, his ſweet diſaſter: with a world
Of pretty fond adoptious chriſtendomes
That blinking Cupid goſſips. Now ſhall he:
I know not what he ſhall, God ſend him well,
The Courts a learning place, and he is one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: What one faith?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: That I wiſh well, ’tis pitty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: What’s pitty?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: That wiſhing well had not a body in’t,
Which might be felt, that we the poorer borne,
Whoſe baſer ſtarres do ſhut vs vp in wiſhes,
Might with effeƈts of them follow our friends,
And ſhew what we alone muſt thinke, which neuer
Returnes vs thankes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pag.
SPEECH.LINE: Monſieur Parrolles,
My Lord cals for you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Little Hellen farewell, if I can remember thee, I
will thinke of thee at Court.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: Monſieur Parolles, you were borne vnder a
charitable ſtarre.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Vnder Mars I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: I eſpecially thinke, vnder Mars.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Why vnder Mars?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: The warres hath ſo kept you vnder, that you
muſt needes be borne vnder Mars.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: When he was predominant.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: When he was retrograde I thinke rather.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Why thinke you ſo?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: You go ſo much backward when you fight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: That’s for aduantage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: So is running away,
When feare propoſes the ſafetie:
But the compoſition that your valour and feare makes
in you, is a vertue of a good wing, and I like the
weare well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Paroll.
SPEECH.LINE: I am ſo full of buſineſſes, I cannot anſwere
thee acutely: I will returne perfeƈt Courtier, in the
which my inſtruƈtion ſhall ſerue to naturalize thee, ſo
thou wilt be capeable of a Courtiers councell, and vn-
derſtand what aduice ſhall thruſt vppon thee, elſe thou
dieſt in thine vnthankfulnes, and thine ignorance makes
thee away, farewell: When thou haſt leyſure, ſay thy
praiers: when thou haſt none, remember thy Friends:
Get thee a good husband, and vſe him as he vſes thee:
So farewell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: Our remedies oft in our ſelues do lye,
Which we aſcribe to heauen: the fated skye
Giues vs free ſcope, onely doth backward pull
Our ſlow deſignes, when we our ſelues are dull.
What power is it, which mounts my loue ſo hye,
That makes me ſee, and cannot feede mine eye?
The mightieſt ſpace in fortune, Nature brings
To ioyne like, likes; and kiſſe like natiue things.
Impoſſible be ſtrange attempts to thoſe
That weigh their paines in ſence, and do ſuppoſe
What hath beene, cannot be. Who euer ſtroue
To ſhew her merit, that did miſſe her loue?
(The Kings diſeaſe) my proieƈt may deceiue me,
But my intents are fixt, and will not leaue me. Exit

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Flouriſh Cornets. Enter the King of France with Letters, and diuers Attendants

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: The Florentines and Senoys are by th’ eares,
Haue fought with equall fortune, and continue
A brauing warre.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Lo.G.
SPEECH.LINE: So tis reported ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay tis moſt credible, we heere receiue it,
A certaintie vouch’d from our Coſin Austria,
With caution, that the Florentine will moue vs
For ſpeedie ayde: wherein our deereſt friend
Preiudicates the buſineſſe, and would ſeeme
To haue vs make deniall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Lo.G.
SPEECH.LINE: His loue and wiſedome
Approu’d ſo to your Maieſty, may pleade
For ampleſt credence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: He hath arm’d our anſwer,
And Florence is deni’de before he comes:
Yet for our Gentlemen that meane to ſee
The Tuſcan ſeruice, freely haue they leaue
To ſtand on either part.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Lo.E.
SPEECH.LINE: It well may ſerue
A nurſſerie to our Gentrie, who are ſicke
For breathing, and exploit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: What’s he comes heere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Lor.G.
SPEECH.LINE: It is the Count Roſignoll my good Lord,
Yong Bertram.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Youth, thou bear’ſt thy Fathers face,
Franke Nature rather curious then in haſt
Hath well compos’d thee: Thy Fathers morall parts
Maiſt thou inherit too: Welcome to Paris.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: My thankes and dutie are your Maieſties.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: I would I had that corporall ſoundneſſe now,
As when thy father, and my ſelfe, in friendſhip
Firſt tride our ſouldierſhip: he did looke farre
Into the ſeruice of the time, and was
Diſcipled of the braueſt. He laſted long,
But on vs both did haggiſh Age ſteale on,
And wore vs out of aƈt: It much repaires me
To talke of your good father; in his youth
He had the wit, which I can well obſerue
To day in our yong Lords: but they may ieſt
Till their owne ſcorne returne to them vnnoted
Ere they can hide their leuitie in honour:
So like a Courtier, contempt nor bitterneſſe
Were in his pride, or ſharpneſſe; if they were,
His equall had awak’d them, and his honour
Clocke to it ſelfe, knew the true minute when
Exception bid him ſpeake: and at this time
His tongue obey’d his hand. Who were below him,
He vs’d as creatures of another place,
And bow’d his eminent top to their low rankes,
Making them proud of his humilitie,
In their poore praiſe he humbled: Such a man
Might be a copie to theſe yonger times;
Which followed well, would demonſtrate them now
But goers backward.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: His good remembrance ſir
Lies richer in your thoughts, then on his tombe:
So in approofe liues not his Epitaph,
As in your royall ſpeech.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Would I were with him he would alwaies ſay,
(Me thinkes I heare him now) his plauſiue words
He ſcatter’d not in eares, but graﬅed them
To grow there and to beare: Let me not liue,
This his good melancholly oﬅ began
On the Cataſtrophe and heele of paſtime
When it was out: Let me not liue (quoth hee)
Aﬅer my ﬂame lackes oyle, to be the ſnuffe
Of yonger ſpirits, whoſe apprehenſiue ſenſes
All but new things diſdaine; whoſe iudgements are
Meere fathers of their garments: whoſe conſtancies
Expire before their faſhions: this he wiſh’d.
I aﬅer him, do aﬅer him wiſh too:
Since I nor wax nor honie can bring home,
I quickly were diſſolued from my hiue
To giue ſome Labourers roome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.L.E.
SPEECH.LINE: You’r loued Sir,
They that leaſt lend it you, ſhall lacke you firſt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: I fill a place I know’t: how long iſt Count
Since the Phyſitian at your fathers died?
He was much fam’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Some ſix moneths ſince my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: If he were liuing, I would try him yet.
Lend me an arme: the reſt haue worne me out
With ſeuerall applications: Nature and ſickneſſe
Debate it at their leiſure. Welcome Count,
My ſonne's no deerer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber
SPEECH.LINE: Thanke your Maieſty.Exit

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coun.
SPEECH.LINE: I will now heare, what ſay you of this gentle-
woman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: Maddam the care I haue had to euen your con-
tent, I wiſh might be found in the Kalender of my paſt
endeuours, for then we wound our Modeſtie, and make
foule the clearneſſe of our deſeruings, when of our ſelues
we publiſh them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coun.
SPEECH.LINE: What dœ’s this knaue heere? Get you gone
ſirra: the complaints I haue heard of you I do not all be-
leeue, ’tis my ſlowneſſe that I dœ not: For I know you
lacke not folly to commit them, & haue abilitie enough
to make ſuch knaueries yours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: ’Tis not vnknown to you Madam, I am a poore
fellow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coun.
SPEECH.LINE: Well ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: No maddam,
’Tis not ſo well that I am poore, though manie
of the rich are damn’d, but if I may haue your Ladiſhips
good will to gœ to the world, Isbell the woman and I
will dœ as we may.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coun.
SPEECH.LINE: Wilt thou needes be a begger?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: I dœ beg your good will in this caſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cou.
SPEECH.LINE: In what caſe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: In Isbels caſe and mine owne: ſeruice is no heri-
tage, and I thinke I ſhall neuer haue the bleſſing of God,
till I haue iſſue a my bodie: for they ſay barnes are bleſ-
ſings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cou.
SPEECH.LINE: Tell me thy reaſon why thou wilt marrie?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: My poore bodie Madam requires it, I am driuen
on by the ﬂeſh, and hee muſt needes gœ that the diuell
driues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cou.
SPEECH.LINE: Is this all your worſhips reaſon?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Faith Madam I haue other holie reaſons, ſuch as
they are.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cou.
SPEECH.LINE: May the world know them?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue beene Madam a wicked creature, as you
and all fleſh and blood are, and indeede I dœ marrie that
I may repent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cou.
SPEECH.LINE: Thy marriage ſooner then thy wickedneſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: I am out a friends Madam, and I hope to haue
friends for my wiues ſake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cou.
SPEECH.LINE: Such friends are thine enemies knaue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Y’are ſhallow Madam in great friends, for the
knaues come to dœ that for me which I am a wearie of:
he that eres my Land, ſpares my teame, and giues mee
leaue to Inne the crop: if I be his cuckold hee's my
drudge; he that comforts my wife, is the cheriſher of
my fleſh and blood; hee that cheriſhes my fleſh and
blood, loues my fleſh and blood; he that loues my fleſh
and blood is my friend: ergo, he that kiſſes my wife is my
friend: if men could be contented to be what they are,
there were no feare in marriage, for yong Charbon the
Puritan, and old Poyſam the Papiſt, how ſomere their
hearts are ſeuer’d in Religion, their heads are both one,
they may ioule horns together like any Deare i’th Herd.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cou.
SPEECH.LINE: Wilt thou euer be a foule mouth’d and calum-
nious knaue?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: A Prophet I Madam, and I ſpeake the truth the
next waie, for I the Ballad will repeate, which men full
true ſhall finde, your marriage comes by deſtinie, your
Cuckow ſings by kinde.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cou.
SPEECH.LINE: Get you gone ſir, Ile talke with you more anon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stew.
SPEECH.LINE: May it pleaſe you Madam, that hee bid Hellen
come to you, of her I am to ſpeake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cou.
SPEECH.LINE: Sirra tell my gentlewoman I would ſpeake with
her, Hellen I meane.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Was this faire face the cauſe, quoth ſhe,
Why the Grecians ſacked Troy,
Fond done, done, fond was this King Priams ioy,
With that ſhe ſighed as ſhe ſtood, bis
And gaue this ſentence then, among nine bad if one be
good, among nine bad if one be good, there’s yet one
good in ten.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cou.
SPEECH.LINE: What, one good in tenne? you corrupt the ſong
ſirra.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: One good woman in ten Madam, which is a pu-
rifying ath’ ſong: would God would ſerue the world ſo
all the yeere, weed finde no fault with the tithe woman
if I were the Parſon, one in ten quoth a? and wee might
haue a good woman borne but ore euerie blazing ſtarre,
or at an earthquake, ’twould mend the Lotterie well, a
man may draw his heart out ere a plucke one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cou.
SPEECH.LINE: Youle begone ſir knaue, and dœ as I command
you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: That man ſhould be at womans command, and
yet no hurt done, though honeſtie be no Puritan, yet
it will dœ no hurt, it will weare the Surplis of humilitie
ouer the blacke-Gowne of a bigge heart: I am go-
ing forſooth, the buſineſſe is for Helen to come hither.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cou.
SPEECH.LINE: Well now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stew.
SPEECH.LINE: I know Madam you loue your Gentlewoman
intirely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cou.
SPEECH.LINE: Faith I dœ: her Father bequeath’d her to mee,
and ſhe her ſelfe without other aduantage, may lawful-
lie make title to as much loue as ſhee findes, there is
more owing her then is paid, and more ſhall be paid
her then ſheele demand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stew.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, I was verie late more neere her then
I thinke ſhee wiſht mee, alone ſhee was, and did
communicate to her ſelfe her owne words to her
owne eares, ſhee thought, I dare vowe for her, they
toucht not anie ſtranger ſence, her matter was, ſhee
loued your Sonne; Fortune ſhee ſaid was no god-
deſſe, that had put ſuch difference betwixt their two
eſtates: Loue no god, that would not extend his might
onelie, where qualities were leuell, Queene of Vir-
gins, that would ſuffer her poore Knight ſurpris’d
without reſcue in the firſt aſſault or ranſome aﬅer-
ward: This ſhee deliuer’d in the moſt bitter touch of
ſorrow that ere I heard Virgin exclaime in, which I held
my dutie ſpeedily to acquaint you withall, ſithence in
the loſſe that may happen, it concernes you ſomething
to know it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cou.
SPEECH.LINE: You haue diſcharg’d this honeſtlie, keepe it
to your ſelfe, manie likelihoods inform’d mee of this
before, which hung ſo tottring in the ballance, that
I could neither beleeue nor miſdoubt: praie you
leaue mee, ſtall this in your boſome, and I thanke
you for your honeſt care: I will ſpeake with you fur-
ther anon. Exit Steward.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Old.Cou.
SPEECH.LINE: Euen ſo it was with me when I was yong:
If euer we are natures, theſe are ours, this thorne
Doth to our Roſe of youth rightlie belong
Our bloud to vs, this to our blood is borne,
It is the ſhow, and ſeale of natures truth,
Where loues ſtrong paſſion is impreſt in youth,
By our remembrances of daies forgon,
Such were our faults, or then we thought them none,
Her eie is ſicke on’t, I obſerue her now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hell.
SPEECH.LINE: What is your pleaſure Madam?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ol.Cou.
SPEECH.LINE: You know Hellen I am a mother to you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hell.
SPEECH.LINE: Mine honorable Miſtris.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ol.Cou.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay a mother, why not a mother? when I ſed a mother
Me thought you ſaw a ſerpent, what’s in mother,
That you ſtart at it? I ſay I am your mother,
And put you in the Catalogue of thoſe
That were enwombed mine, ’tis oﬅen ſeene
Adoption ſtriues with nature, and choiſe breedes
A natiue ſlip to vs from forraine ſeedes:
You nere oppreſt me with a mothers groane,
Yet I expreſſe to you a mothers care,
(Gods mercie maiden) dos it curd thy blood
To ſay I am thy mother? what’s the matter,
That this diſtempered meſſenger of wet?
The manie colour’d Iris rounds thine eye?
— Why, that you are my daughter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hell.
SPEECH.LINE: That I am not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Old.Cou.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſay I am your Mother.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hell.
SPEECH.LINE: Pardon Madam.
The Count Roſillion cannot be my brother:
I am from humble, he from honored name:
No note vpon my Parents, his all noble,
My Maſter, my deere Lord he is, and I
His ſeruant liue, and will his vaſſall die:
He muſt not be my brother.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ol.Cou.
SPEECH.LINE: Nor I your Mother.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hell.
SPEECH.LINE: You are my mother Madam, would you were
So that my Lord your ſonne were not my brother,
Indeede my mother, or were you both our mothers,
I care no more for, then I dœ for heauen,
So I were not his ſiſter, cant no other,
But I your daughter, he muſt be my brother.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Old.Cou.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes Hellen, you might be my daughter in law,
God ſhield you meane it not, daughter and mother
So ſtriue vpon your pulſe; what pale agen?
My feare hath catcht your fondneſſe! now I ſee
The miſtrie of your louelineſſe, and finde
Your ſalt teares head, now to all ſence ’tis groſſe:
You loue my ſonne, inuention is aſham’d
Againſt the proclamation of thy paſſion
To ſay thou dooſt not: therefore tell me true,
But tell me then ’tis ſo, for looke, thy cheekes
Confeſſe it ’ton tooth to th’ other, and thine eies
See it ſo groſely ſhowne in thy behauiours,
That in their kinde they ſpeake it, onely ſinne
And helliſh obſtinacie tye thy tongue
That truth ſhould be ſuspeƈted, ſpeake, iſt ſo?
If it be ſo, you haue wound a goodly clewe:
If it be not, forſweare’t how ere I charge thee,
As heauen ſhall worke in me for thine auaile
To tell me truelie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hell.
SPEECH.LINE: Good Madam pardon me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cou.
SPEECH.LINE: Do you loue my Sonne?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hell.
SPEECH.LINE: Your pardon noble Miſtris.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cou.
SPEECH.LINE: Loue you my Sonne?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hell.
SPEECH.LINE: Dœ not you loue him Madam?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cou.
SPEECH.LINE: Gœ not about; my loue hath in’t a bond
Whereof the world takes note: Come, come, diſcloſe:
The ſtate of your affeƈtion, for your paſſions
Haue to the full appeach’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hell.
SPEECH.LINE: Then I confeſſe
Here on my knee, before high heauen and you,
That before you, and next vnto high heauen, I loue your
Sonne:
My friends were poore but honeſt, ſo's my loue:
Be not offended, for it hurts not him
That he is lou’d of me; I follow him not
By any token of preſumptuous ſuite,
Nor would I haue him, till I dœ deſerue him,
Yet neuer know how that deſert ſhould be:
I know I loue in vaine, ſtriue againſt hope:
Yet in this captious, and intemible Siue.
I ſtill poure in the waters of my loue
And lacke not to looſe ſtill; thus Indian like
Religious in mine error, I adore
The Sunne that lookes vpon his worſhipper,
But knowes of him no more. My deereſt Madam,
Let not your hate incounter with my loue,
For louing where you dœ; but if your ſelfe,
Whoſe aged honor cites a vertuous youth,
Did euer, in ſo true a ﬂame of liking,
Wiſh chaſtly, and loue dearely, that your Dian
Was both her ſelfe and loue, O then giue pittie
To her whoſe ſtate is ſuch, that cannot chooſe
But lend and giue where ſhe is ſure to looſe;
That ſeekes not to finde that, her ſearch implies,
But riddle like, liues ſweetely where ſhe dies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cou.
SPEECH.LINE: Had you not lately an intent, ſpeake truely,
To gœ to Paris?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hell.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam I had.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cou.
SPEECH.LINE: Wherefore? tell true.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hell.
SPEECH.LINE: I will tell truth, by grace it ſelfe I ſweare:
You know my Father left me ſome preſcriptions
Of rare and prou’d effeƈts, ſuch as his reading
And manifeſt experience, had colleƈted
For generall ſoueraigntie: and that he wil’d me
In heedefull’ſt reſeruation to beſtow them,
As notes, whoſe faculties incluſiue were,
More then they were in note: Amongſt the reſt,
There is a remedie, approu’d, ſet downe,
To cure the deſperate languiſhings whereof
The King is render’d loſt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cou.
SPEECH.LINE: This was your motiue for Paris, was it, ſpeake?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hell.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, your ſonne, made me to think of this;
Elſe Paris, and the medicine, and the King,
Had from the conuerſation of my thoughts,
Happily beene abſent then.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cou.
SPEECH.LINE: But thinke you Hellen,
If you ſhould tender your ſuppoſed aide,
He would receiue it? He and his Phiſitions
Are of a minde, he, that they cannot helpe him:
They, that they cannot helpe, how ſhall they credit
A poore vnlearned Virgin, when the Schooles
Embowel’d of their doƈtrine, haue left off
The danger to it ſelfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hell.
SPEECH.LINE: There’s ſomething in’t
More then my Fathers skill, which was the great’ſt
Of his profeſſion, that his good receipt,
Shall for my legacie be ſanƈtified
By th’ luckieſt ſtars in heauen, and would your honor
But giue me leaue to trie ſucceſſe, I’de venture
The well loſt life of mine, on his Graces cure,
By ſuch a day, an houre.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cou.
SPEECH.LINE: Doo’ſt thou beleeue’t?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hell.
SPEECH.LINE: I Madam knowingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cou.
SPEECH.LINE: Why Hellen thou ſhalt haue my leaue and loue,
Meanes and attendants, and my louing greetings
To thoſe of mine in Court, Ile ſtaie at home
And praie Gods bleſſing into thy attempt:
Begon to morrow, and be ſure of this,
What I can helpe thee to, thou ſhalt not miſſe.Exeunt.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter the King with diuers yong Lords, taking leaue for the Florentine warre: Count, Roſſe, and Parrolles. Floriſh Cornets

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Farewell yong Lords, theſe warlike principles
Dœ not throw from you, and you my Lords farewell:
Share the aduice betwixt you, if both gaine, all
The guift doth ſtretch it ſelfe as ’tis receiu’d,
And is enough for both.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lord.G.
SPEECH.LINE: ’Tis our hope ſir,
Aﬅer well entred ſouldiers, to returne
And finde your grace in health.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: No, no, it cannot be; and yet my heart
Will not confeſſe he owes the mallady
That doth my life beſiege: farwell yong Lords,
Whether I liue or die, be you the ſonnes
Of worthy French men: let higher Italy
(Thoſe bated that inherit but the fall
Of the laſt Monarchy) ſee that you come
Not to woœ honour, but to wed it, when
The braueſt queſtant ſhrinkes: finde what you ſeeke,
That fame may cry you loud: I ſay farewell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: L.G.
SPEECH.LINE: Health at your bidding ſerue your Maieſty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Thoſe girles of Italy, take heed of them,
They ſay our French, lacke language to deny
If they demand: beware of being Captiues
Before you ſerue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bo.
SPEECH.LINE: Our hearts receiue your warnings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Farewell, come hether to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Lo.G.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh my ſweet Lord ý you wil ſtay behind vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parr.
SPEECH.LINE: ’Tis not his fault the ſpark.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Lo.E.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh ’tis braue warres.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parr.
SPEECH.LINE: Moſt admirable, I haue ſeene thoſe warres.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſſill.
SPEECH.LINE: I am commanded here, and kept a coyle with,
Too young, and the next yeere, and ’tis too early.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parr.
SPEECH.LINE: And thy minde ſtand too’t boy,
Steale away brauely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſſill.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſhal ſtay here the for-horſe to a ſmocke,
Creeking my ſhoœs on the plaine Maſonry,
Till honour be bought vp, and no ſword worne
But one to dance with: by heauen, Ile ſteale away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Lo.G.
SPEECH.LINE: There’s honour in the theﬅ.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parr.
SPEECH.LINE: Commit it Count.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Lo.E.
SPEECH.LINE: I am your acceſſary, and ſo farewell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: I grow to you, & our parting is a tortur’d body.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Lo.G.
SPEECH.LINE: Farewell Captaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Lo.E.
SPEECH.LINE: Sweet Mounſier Parolles.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parr.
SPEECH.LINE: Noble Herœs; my ſword and yours are kinne,
good ſparkes and luſtrous, a word good mettals. You
ſhall finde in the Regiment of the Spinij, one Captaine
Spurio his ſicatrice, with an Embleme of warre heere on
his ſiniſter cheeke; it was this very ſword entrench’d it:
ſay to him I liue, and obſerue his reports for me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lo.G.
SPEECH.LINE: We ſhall noble Captaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parr.
SPEECH.LINE: Mars doate on you for his nouices, what will
ye dœ?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Stay the King.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parr.
SPEECH.LINE: Vſe a more ſpacious ceremonie to the Noble
Lords, you haue reſtrain’d your ſelfe within the List of
too cold an adieu: be more expreſſiue to them; for they
weare themſelues in the cap of the time, there do muſter
true gate; eat, ſpeake, and moue vnder the inﬂuence of
the moſt receiu’d ſtarre, and though the deuill leade the
meaſure, ſuch are to be followed: aﬅer them, and take a
more dilated farewell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: And I will dœ ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parr.
SPEECH.LINE: Worthy fellowes, and like to prooue moſt ſi-
newie ſword-men. Exeunt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: L.Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Pardon my Lord for mee and for my tidings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile ſee thee to ſtand vp.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: L.Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Then heres a man ſtands that has brought his pardon,
I would you had kneel’d my Lord to aske me mercy,
And that at my bidding you could ſo ſtand vp.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: I would I had, ſo I had broke thy pate
And askt thee mercy for’t.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Goodfaith a-croſſe, but my good Lord ’tis thus,
Will you be cur’d of your infirmitie?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: No.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: O will you eat no grapes my royall foxe?
Yes but you will, my noble grapes, and if
My royall foxe could reach them: I haue ſeen a medicine
That’s able to breath life into a ſtone,
Quicken a rocke, and make you dance Canari
With ſprightly fire and motion, whoſe ſimple touch
Is powerfull to arayſe King Pippen, nay
To giue great Charlemaine a pen in’s hand
And write to her a loue-line.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: What her is this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Why doƈtor ſhe: my Lord, there’s one arriu’d,
If you will ſee her: now by my faith and honour,
If ſeriously I may conuay my thoughts
In this my light deliuerance, I haue ſpoke
With one, that in her ſexe, her yeeres, profeſſion,
Wiſedome and conſtancy, hath amaz’d mee more
Then I dare blame my weakeneſſe: will you ſee her?
For that is her demand, and know her buſineſſe?
That done, laugh well at me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Now good Lafew,
Bring in the admiration, that we with thee
May ſpend our wonder too, or take off thine
By wondring how thou tookſt it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, Ile fit you,
And not be all day neither.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Thus he his ſpeciall nothing euer prologues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, come your waies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: This haſte hath wings indeed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, come your waies,
This is his Maieſtie, ſay your minde to him,
A Traitor you dœ looke like, but ſuch traitors
His Maieſty ſeldome feares, I am Creſſeds Vncle,
That dare leaue two together, far you well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Now faire one, do’s your buſines follow vs?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: I my good Lord,
Gerard de Narbon was my father,
In what he did profeſſe, well found.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: I knew him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: The rather will I ſpare my praiſes towards him,
Knowing him is enough: on’s bed of death,
Many receits he gaue me, chieﬂie one,
Which as the deareſt iſſue of his praƈtice
And of his olde experience, th’ onlie darling,
He bad me ſtore vp, as a triple eye,
Safer then mine owne two: more deare I haue ſo,
And hearing your high Maieſtie is toucht
With that malignant cauſe, wherein the honour
Of my deare fathers giﬅ, ſtands cheefe in power,
I come to tender it, and my appliance,
With all bound humbleneſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: We thanke you maiden,
But may not be ſo credulous of cure,
When our moſt learned Doƈtors leaue vs, and
The congregated Colledge haue concluded,
That labouring Art can neuer ranſome nature
From her inaydible eſtate: I ſay we muſt not
So ſtaine our iudgement, or corrupt our hope,
To proſtitute our paſt-cure malladie
To empericks, or to diſſeuer ſo
Our great ſelfe and our credit, to eſteeme
A ſenceleſſe helpe, when helpe paſt ſence we deeme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hell.
SPEECH.LINE: My dutie then ſhall pay me for my paines:
I will no more enforce mine ofﬁce on you,
Humbly intreating from your royall thoughts,
A modeſt one to beare me backe againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: I cannot giue thee leſſe to be cal’d gratefull:
Thou thoughtſt to helpe me, and ſuch thankes I giue,
As one neere death to thoſe that wiſh him liue:
But what at full I know, thou knowſt no part,
I knowing all my perill, thou no Art.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hell.
SPEECH.LINE: What I can dœ, can dœ no hurt to try,
Since you ſet vp your reſt ’gainſt remedie:
He that of greateſt workes is finiſher,
Oﬅ dœs them by the weakeſt miniſter:
So holy Writ, in babes hath iudgement ſhowne,
When Iudges haue bin babes; great flouds haue flowne
From ſimple ſources: and great Seas haue dried
When Miracles haue by the great’ſt beene denied.
Oﬅ expeƈtation failes, and moſt oﬅ there
Where moſt it promiſes: and oﬅ it hits,
Where hope is coldeſt, and deſpaire moſt ſhiﬅs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: I muſt not heare thee, fare thee wel kind maide,
Thy paines not vs’d, muſt by thy ſelfe be paid,
Proffers not tooke, reape thanks for their reward.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: Inſpired Merit ſo by breath is bard,
It is not ſo with him that all things knowes
As ’tis with vs, that ſquare our gueſſe by ſhowes:
But moſt it is preſumption in vs, when
The help of heauen we count the aƈt of men.
Deare ſir, to my endeauors giue conſent,
Of heauen, not me, make an experiment.
I am not an Impoſture, that proclaime
My ſelfe againſt the leuill of mine aime,
But know I thinke, and thinke I know moſt ſure,
My Art is not paſt power, nor you paſt cure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Art thou ſo confident? Within what ſpace
Hop’ſt thou my cure?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: The greateſt grace lending grace,
Ere twice the horſes of the ſunne ſhall bring
Their fiery torcher his diurnall ring,
Ere twice in murke and occidentall dampe
Moiſt Hesperus hath quench’d her ſleepy Lampe:
Or foure and twenty times the Pylots glaſſe
Hath told the theeuiſh minutes, how they paſſe:
What is infirme, from your ſound parts ſhall flie,
Health ſhall liue free, and ſickeneſſe freely dye.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Vpon thy certainty and confidence,
What dar’ſt thou venter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hell.
SPEECH.LINE: Taxe of impudence,
A ſtrumpets boldneſſe, a divulged ſhame
Traduc’d by odious ballads: my maidens name
Seard otherwiſe, ne worſe of worſt extended
With vildeſt torture, let my life be ended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Methinks in thee ſome bleſſed ſpirit doth ſpeak
His powerfull ſound, within an organ weake:
And what impoſſibility would ſlay
In common ſence, ſence ſaues another way:
Thy life is deere, for all that life can rate
Worth name of life, in thee hath eſtimate:
Youth, beauty, wiſedome, courage, all
That happines and prime, can happy call:
Thou this to hazard, needs muſt intimate
Skill infinite, or monſtrous deſperate,
Sweet praƈtiſer, thy Phyſicke I will try,
That miniſters thine owne death if I die.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: If I breake time, or ﬂinch in property
Of what I ſpoke, vnpittied let me die,
And well deſeru’d: not helping, death’s my fee,
But if I helpe, what dœ you promiſe me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Make thy demand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: But will you make it euen?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: I by my Scepter, and my hopes of helpe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: Then ſhalt thou giue me with thy kingly hand
What husband in thy power I will command:
Exempted be from me the arrogance
To chooſe from forth the royall bloud of France,
My low and humble name to propagate
With any branch or image of thy ſtate:
But ſuch a one thy vaſſall, whom I know
Is free for me to aske, thee to beſtow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere is my hand, the premiſes obſeru’d,
Thy will by my performance ſhall be ſeru’d:
So make the choice of thy owne time, for I
Thy reſolv’d Patient, on thee ſtill relye:
More ſhould I question thee, and more I muſt,
Though more to know, could not be more to truſt:
From whence thou cam’ſt, how tended on, but reſt
Vnqueſtion’d welcome, and vndoubted bleſt.
Giue me ſome helpe heere hoa, if thou proceed,
As high as word, my deed ſhall match thy deed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lady.
SPEECH.LINE: Come on ſir, I ſhall now put you to the height
of your breeding.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown.
SPEECH.LINE: I will ſhew my ſelfe highly fed, and lowly
taught, I know my buſineſſe is but to the Court.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lady.
SPEECH.LINE: To the Court, why what place make you ſpe-
ciall, when you put off that with ſuch contempt, but to
the Court?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Truly Madam, if God haue lent a man any man-
ners, hee may eaſilie put it off at Court: hee that cannot
make a legge, put off’s cap, kiſſe his hand, and ſay no-
thing, has neither legge, hands, lippe, nor cap; and in-
deed ſuch a fellow, to ſay precisely, were not for the
Court, but for me, I haue an anſwere will ſerue all men.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lady.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry that’s a bountifull anſwere that fits all
queſtions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: It is like a Barbers chaire that fits all buttockes,
the pin buttocke, the quatch-buttocke, the brawn but-
tocke, or any buttocke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lady.
SPEECH.LINE: Will your anſwere ſerue fit to all queſtions?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: As fit as ten groats is for the hand of an Attur-
ney, as your French Crowne for your taffety punke, as
Tibs ruſh for Toms fore-ﬁnger, as a pancake for Shroue-
tueſday, a Morris for May-day, as the naile to his hole,
the Cuckold to his horne, as a ſcolding queane to a
wrangling knaue, as the Nuns lip to the Friers mouth,
nay as the pudding to his skin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lady.
SPEECH.LINE: Haue you, I ſay, an anſwere of ſuch fitneſſe for
all queſtions?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: From below your Duke, to beneath your Con-
ſtable, it will fit any queſtion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lady.
SPEECH.LINE: It muſt be an anſwere of moſt monſtrous ſize,
that muſt fit all demands.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: But a triﬂle neither in good faith, if the learned
ſhould ſpeake truth of it: heere it is, and all that belongs
to’t. Aske mee if I am a Courtier, it ſhall dœ you no
harme to learne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lady.
SPEECH.LINE: To be young againe if we could: I will bee
foole in queſtion, hoping to bee the wiſer by your an-
ſwer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray you ſir, are you a Courtier?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: O Lord ſir theres a ſimple putting off: more,
more, a hundred of them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir I am a poore freind of yours, that loues you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: O Lord ſir, thicke, thicke, ſpare not me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: I thinke ſir, you can eate none of this homely
meate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: O Lord ſir; nay put me too’t, I warrant you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: You were lately whipt ſir as I thinke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: O Lord ſir, ſpare not me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: Dœ you crie O Lord ſir at your whipping, and
ſpare not me? Indeed your O Lord ſir, is very ſequent
to your whipping: you would anſwere very well to a
whipping if you were but bound too’t.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: I nere had worſe lucke in my life in my O Lord
ſir: I ſee things may ſerue long, but not ſerue euer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: I play the noble huſwife with the time, to enter-
taine it ſo merrily with a foole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: O Lord ſir, why there’t ſerues well agen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: And end ſir to your buſineſſe: giue Hellen this,
And vrge her to a preſent anſwer backe,
Commend me to my kinſmen, and my ſonne,
This is not much.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Not much commendation to them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: Not much imployement for you, you vnder-
ſtand me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Moſt fruitfully, I am there, before my legges.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La
SPEECH.LINE: Haſt you agen.Exeunt

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ol.Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: They ſay miracles are paſt, and we haue our
Philoſophicall perſons, to make moderne and familiar
things ſupernaturall and cauſeleſſe. Hence is it, that we
make triﬂes of terrours, enſconcing our ſelues into ſee-
ming knowledge, when we ſhould ſubmit our ſelues to
an vnknowne feare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Why ‘tis the rareſt argument of wonder, that
hath ſhot out in our latter times.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: And ſo ’tis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ol.Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: To be relinquiſht of the Artiſts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: So I ſay both of Galen and Paracelsus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ol.Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Of all the learned and authenticke fellowes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Right ſo I ſay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ol.Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: That gaue him out incureable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Why there ’tis, ſo ſay I too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ol.Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Not to be help’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Right, as ’twere a man aſſur’d of a—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ol.Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Vncertaine life, and ſure death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Iuſt, you ſay well: ſo would I haue ſaid.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ol.Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: I may truly ſay, it is a noueltie to the world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: It is indeede if you will haue it in ſhewing, you
ſhall reade it in what do ye call there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ol.Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: A ſhewing of a heauenly effeƈt in an earth-
ly Aƈtor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: That’s it, I would haue ſaid, the verie ſame.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ol.Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Why your Dolphin is not luſtier: fore mee
I ſpeake in respeƈt—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay ’tis ſtrange, ‘tis very ſtraunge, that is the
breefe and the tedious of it, and he's of a moſt facineri-
ous ſpirit, that will not acknowledge it to be the—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ol.Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Very hand of heauen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: I, ſo I ſay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ol.Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: In a moſt weake—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: And debile miniſter great power, great tran-
cendence, which ſhould indeede giue vs a further vſe to
be made, then alone the recou’ry of the king, as to bee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Old Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Generally thankfull.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: I would haue ſaid it, you ſay well: heere comes the King.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ol.Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Luſtique, as the Dutchman ſaies: Ile like a
maide the Better whil’ſt I haue a tooth in my head: why
he’s able to leade her a Carranto.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Mor du vinager, is not this Helen?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ol.Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Fore God I thinke ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Gœ call before mee all the Lords in Court,
Sit my preſeruer by thy patients ſide,
And with this healthfull hand whoſe baniſht ſence
Thou haſt repeal’d, a ſecond time receyue
The confirmation of my promis’d guiﬅ,
Which but attends thy naming.
Faire Maide ſend forth thine eye, this youthfull parcell
Of Noble Batchellors, ſtand at my beſtowing,
Ore whom both Soueraigne power, and fathers voice
I haue to vſe; thy franke eleƈtion make,
Thou haſt power to chooſe, and they none to forſake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: To each of you, one faire and vertuous Miſtris;
Fall when loue pleaſe, marry to each but one.
Old Laf.
I’de giue bay curtall, and his furniture
My mouth no more were broken then theſe boyes,
And writ as little beard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Peruſe them well:
Not one of thoſe, but had a Noble father.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: She addreſſes her to a Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: Gentlemen, heauen hath through me, reſtor’d
the king to health.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All.
SPEECH.LINE: We vnderſtand it, and thanke heauen for you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: I am a ſimple Maide, and therein wealthieſt
That I proteſt, I ſimply am a Maide:
Pleaſe it your Maieſtie, I haue done already:
The bluſhes in my cheekes thus whiſper mee,
We bluſh that thou ſhouldſt chooſe, but be refuſed;
Let the white death ſit on thy cheeke for euer,
Wee’l nere come there againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Make choiſe and ſee,
Who ſhuns thy loue, ſhuns all his loue in mee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: Now Dian from thy Altar do I fly,
And to imperiall loue, that God moſt high
Do my ſighes ſtreame: Sir, wil you heare my ſuite?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Lo.
SPEECH.LINE: And grant it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: Thankes ſir, all the reſt is mute.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ol.Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: I had rather be in this choiſe, then throw
Ameſ-ace for my life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: The honor ſir that ﬂames in your faire eyes,
Before I ſpeake too threatningly replies:
Loue make your fortunes twentie times aboue
Her that ſo wiſhes, and her humble loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Lo.
SPEECH.LINE: No better if you pleaſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: My wiſh receiue,
Which great loue grant, and ſo I take my leaue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ol.Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Do all they denie her? And they were ſons
of mine, I’de haue them whip’d, or I would ſend them
to’th Turke to make Eunuches of.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: Be not afraid that I your hand ſhould take,
Ile neuer do you wrong for your owne ſake:
Bleſſing vpon your vowes, and in your bed
Finde fairer fortune, if you euer wed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Old Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Theſe boyes are boyes of Ice, they’le none
haue heere: ſure they are baſtards to the Engliſh, the
French nere got em.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: You are too young, too happie, and too good
To make your ſelfe a ſonne out of my blood.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 4.Lord.
SPEECH.LINE: Faire one, I thinke not ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ol.Lord
SPEECH.LINE: There’s one grape yet, I am ſure thy father
drunke wine. But if thou be’st not an aſſe, I am a youth
of fourteene: I haue knowne thee already.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: I dare not ſay I take you, but I giue
Me and my ſeruice, euer whilſt I liue
Into your guiding power: This is the man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Why then young Bertram take her ſhee’s thy
wife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: My wife my Leige? I ſhal beſeech your highnes
In ſuch a buſines, giue me leaue to vſe
The helpe of mine owne eies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Know’ſt thou not Bertram what ſhee ha’s
done for mee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes my good Lord, but neuer hope to know
why I ſhould marrie her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou know’ſt ſhee ha’s rais’d me from my ſick-
ly bed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: But followes it my Lord, to bring me downe
Muſt anſwer for your raiſing? I knowe her well:
Shee had her breeding at my fathers charge:
A poore Phyſitians daughter my wife? Diſdaine
Rather corrupt me euer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Tis onely title thou diſdainſt in her, the which
I can build vp: ſtrange is it that our bloods
Of colour, waight, and heat, pour’d all together,
Would quite confound diſtinƈtion: yet ſtands off
In differences ſo mightie. If ſhe bee
All that is vertuous (ſaue what thou diſlik’ſt)
A poore Phiſitians daughter, thou diſlik’ſt
Of vertue for the name: but dœ not ſo:
From loweſt place, whence vertuous things proceed,
The place is digniﬁed by th’ dœrs deede.
Where great additions ſwell's, and vertue none,
It is a dropſied honour. Good alone,
Is good without a name? Vileneſſe is ſo:
The propertie by what is is, ſhould go,
Not by the title. Shee is young, wiſe, faire,
In theſe, to Nature ſhee's immediate heire:
And theſe breed honour: that is honours ſcorne,
Which challenges it ſelfe as honours borne,
And is not like the ſire: Honours thriue,
When rather from our aƈts we them deriue
Then our fore-gœrs: the meere words, a ſlaue
Deboſh’d on euerie tombe, on euerie graue:
A lying Trophee, and as oﬅ is dumbe,
Where duſt, and damn’d obliuion is the Tombe.
Of honour’d bones indeed, what ſhould be ſaide?
If thou canſt like this creature, as a maide,
I can create the reſt: Vertue, and ſhee
Is her owne dower: Honour and wealth, from mee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: I cannot loue her, nor will ſtriue to doo’t.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou wrong’ſt thy ſelfe, if thou ſhold’ſt ſtriue
to chooſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: That you are well reſtor’d my Lord, I’me glad:
Let the reſt go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: My Honor’s at the ſtake, which to defeate
I muſt produce my power. Heere, take her hand,
Proud ſcornfull boy, vnworthie this good giﬅ,
That doſt in vile miſpriſion ſhackle vp
My loue, and her deſert: that canſt not dreame,
We poizing vs in her defeƈtiue ſcale,
Shall weigh thee to the beame: That wilt not know,
It is in Vs to plant thine Honour, where
We pleaſe to haue it grow. Checke thy contempt:
Obey Our will, which trauailes in thy good:
Beleeue not thy diſdaine, but preſentlie
Do thine owne fortunes that obedient right
Which both thy dutie owes, and Our power claimes,
Or I will throw thee from my care for euer
Into the ſtaggers, and the careleſſe lapſe
Of youth and ignorance: both my reuenge and hate
Looſing vpon thee, in the name of iuſtice,
Without all termes of pittie. Speake, thine anſwer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Pardon my gracious Lord: for I ſubmit
My fancie to your eies, when I conſider
What great creation, and what dole of honour
Flies where you bid it: I finde that ſhe which late
Was in my Nobler thoughts, moſt baſe: is now
The praiſed of the King, who ſo ennobled,
Is as ’twere borne ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Take her by the hand,
And tell her ſhe is thine: to whom I promiſe
A counterpoize: If not to thy eſtate,
A ballance more repleat.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: I take her hand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Good fortune, and the fauour of the King
Smile vpon this Contraƈt: whoſe Ceremonie
Shall ſeeme expedient on the now borne briefe,
And be perform’d to night: the ſolemne Feaſt
Shall more attend vpon the coming ſpace,
Expeƈting abſent friends. As thou lou’ſt her,
Thy loue’s to me Religious: elſe, do’s erre. Exeunt

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Parolles and Lafew ſtay behind, commenting of this wedding

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Do you heare Monſieur? A word with you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Your pleaſure ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Your Lord and Maſter did well to make his re-
cantation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Recantation? My Lord? my Maſter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: I: Is it not a Language I ſpeake?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: A moſt harſh one, and not to bee vnderſtoode
without bloudie ſucceeding. My Maſter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Are you Companion to the Count Roſillion?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: To any Count, to all Counts: to what is man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: To what is Counts man: Counts maiſter is of
another ſtile.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: You are too old ſir: Let it ſatisﬁe you, you are
too old.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: I muſt tell thee ſirrah, I write Man: to which
title age cannot bring thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: What I dare too well do, I dare not do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: I did thinke thee for two ordinaries: to bee a
prettie wiſe fellow, thou didſt make tollerable vent of
thy trauell, it might paſſe: yet the ſcarffes and the ban-
nerets about thee, did manifoldlie diſſwade me from be-
leeuing thee a veſſell of too great a burthen. I haue now
found thee, when I looſe thee againe, I care not: yet art
thou good for nothing but taking vp, and that th’ourt
ſcarce worth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Hadſt thou not the priuiledge of Antiquity vp-
on thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Do not plundge thy ſelfe to farre in anger, leaſt
thou haſten thy triall: which if, Lord haue mercie on
thee for a hen, ſo my good window of Lettice fare thee
well, thy caſement I neede not open, for I look through
thee. Giue me thy hand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, you giue me moſt egregious indignity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: I with all my heart, and thou art worthy of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue not my Lord deseru’d it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes good faith, eu’ry dramme of it, and I will
not bate thee a ſcruple.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, I ſhall be wiſer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Eu’n as ſoone as thou can’ſt, for thou haſt to pull
at a ſmacke a’th contrarie. If euer thou bee’ſt bound
in thy ſkarfe and beaten, thou ſhall finde what it is to be
proud of thy bondage, I haue a deſire to holde my ac-
quaintance with thee, or rather my knowledge, that I
may ſay in the default, he is a man I know.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord you do me moſt inſupportable vexati-
on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: I would it were hell paines for thy ſake, and my
poore doing eternall: for doing I am paſt, as I will by
thee, in what motion age will giue me leaue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, thou haſt a ſonne ſhall take this diſgrace
off me; ſcuruy, old, filthy, ſcuruy Lord: Well, I muſt
be patient, there is no fettering of authority. Ile beate
him (by my life) if I can meete him with any conueni-
ence, and he were double and double a Lord. Ile haue
no more pittie of his age then I would haue of— Ile
beate him, and if I could but meet him agen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Sirra, your Lord and maſters married, there’s
newes for you: you haue a new Miſtris.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: I moſt vnfainedly beſeech your Lordſhippe to
make ſome reſeruation of your wrongs. He is my good
Lord, whom I ſerue aboue is my maſter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Who? God.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: The deuill it is, that’s thy master. Why doœſt
thou garter vp thy armes a this faſhion? Doſt make hoſe
of thy ſleeues? Do other ſeruants ſo? Thou wert beſt ſet
thy lower part where thy noſe ſtands. By mine Honor,
if I were but two houres yonger, I’de beate thee: mee-
think’ſt thou art a generall offence, and euery man ſhold
beate thee: I thinke thou waſt created for men to breath
themſelues vpon thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: This is hard and vndeſerued meaſure my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Go too ſir, you were beaten in Italy for picking
a kernell out of a Pomgranat, you are a vagabond, and
no true traueller: you are more ſawcie with Lordes and
honourable perſonages, then the Commiſſion of your
birth and vertue giues you Heraldry. You are not worth
another word, elſe I’de call you knaue. I leaue you. Exit

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Good, very good, it is ſo then: good, very
good, let it be conceal’d awhile.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Vndone, and forfeited to cares for euer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: What's the matter ſweet-heart?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſſill.
SPEECH.LINE: Although before the ſolemne Prieſt I haue
ſworne, I will not bed her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: What? what ſweet heart?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: O my Parrolles, they haue married me:
Ile to the Tuſcan warres, and neuer bed her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: France is a dog-hole, and it no more merits,
The tread of a mans foot: too’th warres.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: There’s letters from my mother: What th’ im-
port is, I know not yet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: I that would be knowne: too’th warrs my boy,
too’th warres:
He weares his honor in a boxe vnſeene,
That hugges his kickie wickie heare at home,
Spending his manlie marrow in her armes
Which ſhould ſustaine the bound and high curuet
Of Marses fierie ſteed: to other Regions,
France is a ſtable, wee that dwell in’t Iades,
Therefore too’th warre.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: It ſhall be ſo, Ile ſend her to my houſe,
Acquaint my mother with my hate to her,
And wherefore I am fled: Write to the King
That which I durſt not ſpeake. His preſent giﬅ
Shall furniſh me to thoſe Italian fields
Where noble fellowes ſtrike: Warres is no ſtrife
To the darke houſe, and the deteƈted wife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Will this Caprichio hold in thee, art ſure?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Go with me to my chamber, and aduice me.
Ile ſend her ſtraight away: To morrow,
Ile to the warres, ſhe to her ſingle ſorrow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Why theſe bals bound, ther's noiſe in it. Tis hard
A yong man maried, is a man that’s mard:
Therefore away, and leaue her brauely: go,
The King ha’s done you wrong: but huſh ’tis ſo.Exit

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: My mother greets me kindly, is ſhe well?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: She is not well, but yet ſhe has her health, ſhe’s
very merrie, but yet ſhe is not well: but thankes be gi-
uen ſhe's very well, and wants nothing i’th world: but
yet ſhe is not well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: If ſhe be verie wel, what do’s ſhe ayle, that ſhe’s
not verie well?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Truly ſhe’s very well indeed, but for two things

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: What two things?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: One, that ſhe's not in heauen, whether God ſend
her quickly: the other, that ſhe’s in earth, from whence
God ſend her quickly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Bleſſe you my fortunate Ladie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: I hope ſir I haue your good will to haue mine
owne good fortune.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: You had my prayers to leade them on, and to
keepe them on, haue them ſtill. O my knaue, how do’s
my old Ladie?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: So that you had her wrinkles, and I her money,
I would ſhe did as you ſay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Why I ſay nothing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry you are the wiſer man: for many a mans
tongue ſhakes out his maſters vndoing: to ſay nothing,
to do nothing, to know nothing, and to haue nothing,
is to be a great part of your title, which is within a verie
little of nothing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Away, th’art a knaue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: You ſhould haue ſaid ſir before a knaue, th’art a
knaue, that’s before me th’art a knaue: this had beene
truth ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Go too, thou art a wittie foole, I haue found
thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Did you finde me in your ſelfe ſir, or were you
taught to finde me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: The ſearch ſir was profitable, and much Foole
may you find in you, euen to the worlds pleaſure, and the
encreaſe of laughter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: A good knaue ifaith, and well fed.
Madam, my Lord will go awaie to night,
A verie ſerrious buſineſſe call’s on him:
The great prerogatiue and rite of loue,
Which as your due time claimes, he do’s acknowledge,
But puts it off to a compell’d reſtraint:
Whoſe want, and whoſe delay, is ſtrew’d with ſweets
Which they diſtill now in the curbed time,
To make the comming houre oreflow with ioy,
And pleaſure drowne the brim.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: What's his will elſe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: That you will take your inſtant leaue a’th king,
And make this haſt as your owne good proceeding,
Strengthned with what Apologie you thinke
May make it probable neede.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: What more commands hee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: That hauing this obtain’d, you preſentlie
Attend his further pleaſure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: In euery thing I waite vpon his will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par
SPEECH.LINE: I ſhall report it ſo. Exit Par.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hell
SPEECH.LINE: I pray you come ſirrah. Exit

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: But I hope your Lordſhippe thinkes not him a
ſouldier.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes my Lord and of verie valiant approofe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: You haue it from his owne deliuerance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: And by other warranted teſtimonie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Then my Diall goes not true, I tooke this Larke
for a bunting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: I do aſſure you my Lord he is very great in know-
ledge, and accordinglie valiant.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue then ſinn’d against his experience, and
tranſgreſt againſt his valour, and my ſtate that way is
dangerous, ſince I cannot yet find in my heart to repent:
Heere he comes, I pray you make vs freinds, I will pur-
sue the amitie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Theſe things ſhall be done ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray you ſir whoſe his Tailor?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: O I know him well, I ſir, hee ſirs a good worke-
man, a verie good Tailor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Is ſhee gone to the king?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Shee is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Will ſhee away to night?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: As you’le haue her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue writ my letters, casketted my treaſure,
Giuen order for our horses, and to night,
When I ſhould take poſſeſſion of the Bride,
And ere I dœ begin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: A good Trauailer is ſomething at the latter end
of a dinner, but on that lies three thirds, and vſes a
known truth to paſſe a thouſand nothings with, ſhould
bee once hard, and thrice beaten. God ſaue you Cap-
taine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Is there any vnkindnes betweene my Lord and
you Monſieur?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: I know not how I haue deſerued to run into my
Lords diſpleaſure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: You haue made ſhift to run into’t, bootes and
ſpurres and all: like him that leapt into the Cuſtard, and
out of it you’le runne againe, rather then ſuffer queſtion
for your reſidence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: It may bee you haue miſtaken him my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: And ſhall dœ ſo euer, though I tooke him at’s
prayers. Fare you well my Lord, and beleeue this of
me, there can be no kernell in this light Nut: the ſoule
of this man is his cloathes: Truſt him not in matter of
heauie conſequence: I haue kept of them tame, & know
their natures. Farewell Monſieur, I haue ſpoken better
of you, then you haue or will to deſerue at my hand, but
we muſt do good againſt euill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: An idle Lord, I ſweare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: I thinke ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Why do you not know him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes, I do know him well, and common ſpeech
Giues him a worthy paſſe. Heere comes my clog.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue ſir as I was commanded from you
Spoke with the King, and haue procur’d his leaue
For preſent parting, onely he deſires
Some priuate ſpeech with you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſhall obey his will.
You muſt not meruaile Helen at my courſe,
Which holds not colour with the time, nor dœs
The miniſtration, and required ofﬁce
On my particular. Prepar’d I was not
For ſuch a buſineſſe, therefore am I found
So much vnſetled: This driues me to intreate you,
That preſently you take your way for home,
And rather muſe then aske why I intreate you,
For my reſpeƈts are better then they ſeeme,
And my appointments haue in them a neede
Greater then ſhewes it ſelfe at the firſt view,
To you that know them not. This to my mother,
’Twill be two daies ere I ſhall ſee you, ſo
I leaue you to your wiſedome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, I can nothing ſay,
But that I am your moſt obedient ſeruant.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come, no more of that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: And euer ſhall
With true obſeruance ſeeke to eeke out that
Wherein toward me my homely ſtarres haue faild
To equall my great fortune.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Let that gœ: my haſt is verie great. Farwell:
Hie home.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray ſir your pardon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, what would you ſay?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: I am not worthie of the wealth I owe,
Nor dare I ſay ’tis mine: and yet it is,
But like a timorous theefe, moſt faine would ſteale
What law dœs vouch mine owne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: What would you haue?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: Something, and ſcarse ſo much: nothing indeed,
I would not tell you what I would my Lord: Faith yes,
Strangers and fœs do ſunder, and not kiſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray you ſtay not, but in haſt to horſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſhall not breake your bidding, good my Lord:
Where are my other men? Monſieur, farwell. Exit

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Go thou toward home, where I wil neuer come,
Whilſt I can ſhake my ſword, or heare the drumme:
Away, and for our flight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Brauely, Coragio.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Flouriſh. Enter the Duke of Florence, the two Frenchmen,with a troope of Souldiers

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: So that from point to point, now haue you heard
The fundamentall reaſons of this warre,
Whoſe great deciſion hath much blood let forth
And more thirſts aﬅer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Lord.
SPEECH.LINE: Holy ſeemes the quarrell
Vpon your Graces part: blacke and fearefull
On the oppoſer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Therefore we meruaile much our Coſin France
Would in ſo iust a buſineſſe, ſhut his boſome
Againſt our borrowing prayers.
French E.
Good my Lord,
The reaſons of our ſtate I cannot yeelde,
But like a common and an outward man,
That the great figure of a Counſaile frames,
By ſelfe vnable motion, therefore dare not
Say what I thinke of it, ſince I haue found
My ſelfe in my incertaine grounds to faile
As oﬅen as I gueſt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Be it his pleaſure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fren.G.
SPEECH.LINE: But I am ſure the yonger of our nature,
That ſurfet on their ease, will day by day
Come heere for Phyſicke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Welcome ſhall they bee:
And all the honors that can flye from vs,
Shall on them ſettle: you know your places well,
When better fall, for your auailes they fell,
To morrow to’th the field.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Count.
SPEECH.LINE: It hath happen’d all, as I would haue had it, ſaue
that he comes not along with her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: By my troth I take my young Lord to be a ve-
rie melancholly man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Count.
SPEECH.LINE: By what obſeruance I pray you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Why he will looke vppon his boote, and ſing:
mend the Ruffe and ſing, aske queſtions and ſing, picke
his teeth, and ſing: I know a man that had this tricke of
melancholy hold a goodly Mannor for a ſong.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lad.
SPEECH.LINE: Let me ſee what he writes, and when he meanes
to come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clow.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue no minde to Isbell ſince I was at Court.
Our old Lings, and our Isbels a’th Country, are nothing
like your old Ling and your Isbels a’th Court: the brains
of my Cupid's knock’d out, and I beginne to loue, as an
old man loues money, with no ſtomacke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lad.
SPEECH.LINE: What haue we heere?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo
SPEECH.LINE: In that you haue there.

LINE.ITALIC: I haue ſent you a daughter-in-Law, ſhee hath recouered the
King, and vndone me: I haue wedded her, not bedded her,
and ſworne to make the not eternall. You ſhall heare I am
runne away, know it before the report come. If there bee
bredth enough in the world, I will hold a long diſtance. My
duty to you. Your vnfortunate ſonne,

SPEECH.LINE: Bertram.
This is not well raſh and vnbridled boy,
To flye the fauours of ſo good a King,
To plucke his indignation on thy head,
By the miſpriſing of a Maide too vertuous
For the contempt of Empire.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clow.
SPEECH.LINE: O Madam, yonder is heauie newes within be-
tweene two ſouldiers, and my yong Ladie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: What is the matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay there is ſome comfort in the newes, ſome
comfort, your ſonne will not be kild ſo ſoone as I thoght
he would.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: Why ſhould he be kill’d?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: So ſay I Madame, if he runne away, as I heare he
dœs, the danger is in ſtanding too’t, that’s the loſſe of
men, though it be the getting of children. Heere they
come will tell you more. For my part I onely heare your
ſonne was run away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: French E.
SPEECH.LINE: Saue you good Madam.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, my Lord is gone, for euer gone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: French G.
SPEECH.LINE: Do not ſay ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: Thinke vpon patience, pray you Gentlemen,
I haue felt ſo many quirkes of ioy and greefe,
That the firſt face of neither on the ſtart
Can woman me vntoo’t. Where is my ſonne I pray you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fren.G.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam he’s gone to ſerue the Duke of Flo-
rence,
We met him thitherward, for thence we came:
And after ſome diſpatch in hand at Court,
Thither we bend againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: Looke on his Letter Madam, here’s my Paſport.

LINE.ITALIC: When thou canſt get the Ring vpon my ﬁnger, which neuer
ſhall come off, and ſhew mee a childe begotten of thy bodie,
that I am father too, then call me husband: but in ſuch a (then)
I write a Neuer.

SPEECH.LINE: This is a dreadfull ſentence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: Brought you this Letter Gentlemen?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.G.
SPEECH.LINE: I Madam, and for the Contents ſake are ſorrie
for our paines.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Old La.
SPEECH.LINE: I prethee Ladie haue a better cheere,
If thou engroſſeſt, all the greefes are thine,
Thou robſt me of a moity: He was my ſonne,
But I do wash his name out of my blood,
And thou art all my childe. Towards Florence is he?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fren.G.
SPEECH.LINE: I Madam.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: And to be a ſouldier.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fren.G.
SPEECH.LINE: Such is his noble purpoſe, and beleeu’t
The Duke will lay vpon him all the honor
That good conuenience claimes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: Returne you thither.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fren.E.
SPEECH.LINE: I Madam, with the ſwifteſt wing of ſpeed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.

LINE.ITALIC: Till I haue no wife, I haue nothing in France,

SPEECH.LINE: ’Tis bitter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: Finde you that there?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: I Madame.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fren.E.
SPEECH.LINE: ’Tis but the boldneſſe of his hand haply, which
his heart was not conſenting too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lad.
SPEECH.LINE: Nothing in France, vntill he haue no wife:
There's nothing heere that is too good for him
But onely ſhe, and ſhe deſerues a Lord
That twenty ſuch rude boyes might tend vpon,
And call her hourely Miſtris. Who was with him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fren.E.
SPEECH.LINE: A ſeruant onely, and a Gentleman: which I
haue ſometime knowne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: Parolles was it not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fren.E.
SPEECH.LINE: I my good Ladie, hee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: A verie tainted fellow, and full of wickedneſſe,
My ſonne corrupts a well deriued nature
With his inducement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fren.E.
SPEECH.LINE: Indeed good Ladie the fellow has a deale of
that, too much, which holds him much to haue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: Y’are welcome Gentlemen, I will intreate you
when you ſee my ſonne, to tell him that his ſword can
neuer winne the honor that he looſes: more Ile intreate
you written to beare along.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fren.G.
SPEECH.LINE: We ſerue you Madam in that and all your
worthieſt affaires.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: Not ſo, but as we change our courteſies,
Will you draw neere?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.

LINE.ITALIC: Till I haue no wife I haue nothing in France.

SPEECH.LINE: Nothing in France vntill he has no wife:
Thou ſhalt haue none Roſſillion, none in France,
Then haſt thou all againe: poore Lord, is’t I
That chaſe thee from thy Countrie, and expoſe
Thoſe tender limbes of thine, to the euent
Of the none-ſparing warre? And is it I,
That driue thee from the ſportiue Court, where thou
Was’t ſhot at with faire eyes, to be the marke
Of ſmoakie Muskets? O you leaden meſſengers,
That ride vpon the violent ſpeede of fire,
Fly with falſe ayme, moue the ſtill-peering aire
That ſings with piercing, do not touch my Lord:
Who euer ſhoots at him, I ſet him there.
Who euer charges on his forward breſt
I am the Caitiffe that do hold him too’t,
And though I kill him not, I am the cauſe
His death was ſo effeƈted: Better ’twere
I met the rauine Lyon when he roar’d
With ſharpe conſtraint of hunger: better ’twere,
That all the miſeries which nature owes
Were mine at once. No come thou home Roſſillion,
Whence honor but of danger winnes a ſcarre,
As oﬅ it looſes all. I will be gone:
My being heere it is, that holds thee hence,
Shall I ſtay heere to doo’t? No, no, although
The ayre of Paradiſe did fan the houſe,
And Angels offic’d all: I will be gone,
That pittifull rumour may report my flight
To conſolate thine eare. Come night, end day,
For with the darke (poore theefe) Ile ſteale away. Exit.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Flouriſh. Enter the Duke of Florence, Roſſillion, drum and trumpets, ſoldiers, Parrolles

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: The Generall of our horſe thou art, and we
Great in our hope, lay our beſt loue and credence
Vpon thy promiſing fortune.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir it is
A charge too heauy for my ſtrength, but yet
Wee’l ſtriue to beare it for your worthy ſake,
To th’ extreme edge of hazard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Then go thou forth,
And fortune play vpon thy proſperous helme
As thy auſpicious miſtris.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: This very day
Great Mars I put my ſelfe into thy file,
Make me but like my thoughts, and I ſhall proue
A louer of thy drumme, hater of loue.Exeunt omnes

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: Alas! and would you take the letter of her:
Might you not know ſhe would do, as ſhe has done,
By ſending me a Letter. Reade it agen.

LINE.ITALIC: I am S[aint]. Iaques Pilgrim, thither gone:
Ambitious loue hath ſo in me offended,
That bare-foot plod I the cold ground vpon
With ſainted vow my faults to haue amended
Write, write, that from the bloodie courſe of warre,
My deereſt Maſter your deare ſonne, may hie,
Bleſſe him at home in peace. Whilſt I from farre,
His name with zealous feruour ſanƈtifie:
His taken labours bid him me forgiue:
I his deſpightfull Iuno ſent him forth,
From Courtly friends, with Camping fœs to liue,
Where death and danger dogges the heeles of worth.
He is too good and faire for death, and mee,
Whom I my ſelfe embrace, to ſet him free.

SPEECH.LINE: Ah what ſharpe ſtings are in her mildeſt words?
Rynaldo, you did neuer lacke aduice ſo much,
As letting her paſſe ſo: had I ſpoke with her,
I could haue well diuerted her intents,
Which thus ſhe hath preuented.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: Pardon me Madam,
If I had giuen you this at ouer-night,
She might haue beene ore-tane: and yet ſhe writes
Purſuite would be but vaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: What Angell ſhall
Bleſſe this vnworthy husband, he cannot thriue,
Vnleſſe her prayers, whom heauen delights to beare
And loues to grant, repreeue him from the wrath
Of greateſt Iustice. Write, write Rynaldo,
To this vnworthy husband of his wife,
Let euerie word waigh heauie of her worth,
That he dœs waigh too light: my greateſt greefe,
Though little he do feele it, ſet downe ſharpely.
Diſpatch the moſt conuenient meſſenger,
When haply he ſhall heare that ſhe is gone,
He will returne, and hope I may that ſhee
