Hearing ſo much, will ſpeede her foote againe,
Led hither by pure loue: which of them both
Is deereſt to me, I haue no ſkill in ſence
To make diſtinƈtion: prouide this Meſſenger:
My heart is heauie, and mine age is weake,
Greefe would haue teares, and ſorrow bids me ſpeake.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter old Widdow of Florence, her daughter Violenta and Mariana, with other Citizens

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Widdow.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay come,
For if they do approach the Citty,
We ſhall looſe all the ſight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Diana.
SPEECH.LINE: They ſay, the French Count has done
Moſt honourable ſeruice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wid.
SPEECH.LINE: It is reported,
That he has taken their great’ſt Commander,
And that with his owne hand he ſlew
The Dukes brother: we haue loſt our labour,
They are gone a contrarie way: harke,
you may know by their Trumpets.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maria.
SPEECH.LINE: Come lets returne againe,
And ſuffice our ſelues with the report of it.
Well Diana, take heed of this French Earle,
The honor of a Maide is her name,
And no Legacie is ſo rich
As honeſtie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Widdow.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue told my neighbour
How you haue beene ſolicited by a Gentleman
His Companion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maria.
SPEECH.LINE: I know that knaue, hang him, one Parolles,
a filthy Officer he is in thoſe ſuggeſtions for the young
Earle, beware of them Diana; their promiſes, entiſe-
ments, oathes, tokens, and all theſe engines of luſt, are
not the things they go vnder: many a maide hath beene
ſeduced by them, and the miſerie is example, that ſo
terrible ſhewes in the wracke of maiden-hood, cannot
for all that diſſwade ſucceſſion, but that they are limed
with the twigges that threatens them. I hope I neede
not to aduiſe you further, but I hope your owne grace
will keepe you where you are, though there were no
further danger knowne, but the modeſtie which is ſo
loſt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: You ſhall not neede to feare me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wid.
SPEECH.LINE: I hope ſo: looke here comes a pilgrim, I know
ſhe will lye at my houſe, thither they ſend one another,
Ile queſtion her. God ſaue you pilgrim, whether are
bound?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: To S[aint]. Iaques la grand.
Where do the Palmers lodge, I do beſeech you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wid.
SPEECH.LINE: At the S[aint]. Francis heere beſide the Port.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel
SPEECH.LINE: Is this the way?A march afarre.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wid.
SPEECH.LINE: I marrie iſt. Harke you, they come this way:
If you will tarrie holy Pilgrime
But till the troopes come by,
I will conduƈt you where you ſhall be lodg’d,
The rather for I thinke I know your hoſteſſe
As ample as my ſelfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: Is it your ſelfe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wid.
SPEECH.LINE: If you ſhall pleaſe ſo Pilgrime.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: I thanke you, and will ſtay vpon your leiſure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wid.
SPEECH.LINE: You came I thinke from France?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: I did ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wid.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere you ſhall ſee a Countriman of yours
That has done worthy ſeruice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: His name I pray you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: The Count Roſſillion: know you ſuch a one?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: But by the eare that heares moſt nobly of him:
His face I know not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſomere he is
He’s brauely taken heere. He ſtole from France
As ’tis reported: for the King had married him
Againſt his liking. Thinke you it is ſo?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſurely meere the truth, I know his Lady.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: There is a Gentleman that ſerues the Count,
Reports but courſely of her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: What’s his name?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: Monſieur Parrolles.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh I beleeue with him,
In argument of praiſe, or to the worth
Of the great Count himſelfe, ſhe is too meane
To haue her name repeated, all her deſeruing
Is a reſerued honeſtie, and that
I haue not heard examin’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dian.
SPEECH.LINE: Alas poore Ladie,
’Tis a hard bondage to become the wife
Of a deteſting Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wid.
SPEECH.LINE: I write good creature, wheresœre ſhe is,
Her hart waighes ſadly: this yong maid might do her
A ſhrewd turne if ſhe pleas’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: How do you meane?
May be the amorous Count ſolicites her
In the vnlawfull purpoſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wid.
SPEECH.LINE: He dœs indeede,
And brokes with all that can in ſuch a ſuite
Corrupt the tender honour of a Maide:
But ſhe is arm’d for him, and keepes her guard
In honeſteſt defence.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Drumme and Colours. Enter Count Roſſillion, Parrolles, and the whole Armie

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: The goddes forbid elſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wid.
SPEECH.LINE: So, now they come:
That is Anthonio the Dukes eldeſt ſonne,
That Eſcalus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: Which is the Frenchman?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: Hee,
That with the plume, ’tis a moſt gallant fellow,
I would he lou’d his wife: if he were honeſter
He were much goodlier. Is’t not a handſom Gentleman

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: I like him well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Di.
SPEECH.LINE: ’Tis pitty he is not honeſt: yonds that ſame knaue
That leades him to theſe places: were I his Ladie,
I would poiſon that vile Raſcall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: Which is he?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: That Iacke-an-apes with ſcarfes. Why is hee
melancholly?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: Perchance he’s hurt i’th battaile.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Looſe our drum? Well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: He’s ſhrewdly vext at ſomething. Looke he
has ſpyed vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wid.
SPEECH.LINE: Marrie hang you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar
SPEECH.LINE: And your curteſie, for a ring-carrier.Exit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wid.
SPEECH.LINE: The troope is paſt: Come pilgrim, I wil bring
you, Where you ſhall hoſt: Of inioyn’d penitents
There’s foure or fiue, to great S[aint]. Iaques bound,
Alreadie at my houſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: I humbly thanke you:
Pleaſe it this Matron, and this gentle Maide
To eate with vs to night, the charge and thanking
Shall be for me, and to requite you further,
I will beſtow ſome precepts of this Virgin,
Worthy the note.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Both
SPEECH.LINE: Wee’l take your offer kindly.Exeunt.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Count Roſſillion and the Frenchmen, as at firſt

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.E.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay good my Lord put him too’t: let him
haue his way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.G.
SPEECH.LINE: If your Lordſhippe finde him not a Hilding,
hold me no more in your reſpeƈt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.E.
SPEECH.LINE: On my life my Lord, a bubble.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Do you thinke I am ſo farre
Deceiued in him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.E.
SPEECH.LINE: Beleeue it my Lord, in mine owne direƈt
knowledge, without any malice, but to ſpeake of him
as my kinſman, hee’s a moſt notable Coward, an infi-
nite and endleſſe Lyar, an hourely promiſe-breaker, the
owner of no one good qualitie, worthy your Lordſhips
entertainment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.G.
SPEECH.LINE: It were fit you knew him, leaſt repoſing too
farre in his vertue which he hath not, he might at ſome
great and truſtie buſineſſe, in a maine daunger, fayle
you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: I would I knew in what particular aƈtion to try
him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.G.
SPEECH.LINE: None better then to let him fetch off his
drumme, which you heare him ſo conﬁdently vnder-
take to do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: C.E.
SPEECH.LINE: I with a troop of Florentines wil ſodainly ſur-
prize him; ſuch I will haue whom I am ſure he knowes
not from the enemie: wee will binde and hoodwinke
him ſo, that he ſhall ſuppoſe no other but that he is car-
ried into the Leager of the aduerſaries, when we bring
him to our owne tents: be but your Lordſhip preſent
at his examination, if he do not for the promiſe of his
life, and in the higheſt compulſion of baſe feare, offer to
betray you, and deliuer all the intelligence in his power
againſt you, and that with the diuine forfeite of his
ſoule vpon oath, neuer truſt my iudgement in anie
thing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.G.
SPEECH.LINE: O for the loue of laughter, let him fetch his
drumme, he ſayes he has a ſtratagem for’t: when your
Lordſhip ſees the bottome of this ſucceſſe in’t, and to
what mettle this counterfeyt lump of ours will be mel-
ted if you giue him not Iohn drummes entertainement,
your inclining cannot be remoued. Heere he comes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.E.
SPEECH.LINE: O for the loue of laughter hinder not the ho-
nor of his deſigne, let him fetch off his drumme in any
hand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: How now Monſieur? This drumme ſticks ſore-
ly in your diſpoſition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.G.
SPEECH.LINE: A pox on’t, let it go, ’tis but a drumme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: But a drumme: Iſt but a drumme? A drum ſo
loſt. There was excellent command, to charge in with
our horſe vpon our owne wings, and to rend our owne
ſouldiers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.G.
SPEECH.LINE: That was not to be blam’d in the command
of the ſeruice: it was a diſaſter of warre that Cæſar him
ſelfe could not haue preuented, if he had beene there to
command.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, wee cannot greatly condemne our ſuc-
ceſſe: ſome diſhonor wee had in the loſſe of that drum,
but it is not to be recouered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: It might haue beene recouered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: It might, but it is not now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: It is to be recouered, but that the merit of ſer-
uice is ſildome attributed to the true and exaƈt perfor-
mer, I would haue that drumme or another, or hic ia-
cet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Why if you haue a ſtomacke, too’t Monſieur: if
you thinke your myſterie in ſtratagem, can bring this
inſtrument of honour againe into his natiue quarter, be
magnanimious in the enterprize and go on, I wil grace
the attempt for a worthy exploit: if you ſpeede well in
it, the Duke ſhall both ſpeake of it, and extend to you
what further becomes his greatneſſe, euen to the vtmo>ſt
ſyllable of your worthineſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: By the hand of a ſouldier I will vndertake it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: But you mu>ſt not now ſlumber in it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile about it this euening, and I will preſently
pen downe my dilemma’s, encourage my ſelfe in my
certaintie, put my ſelfe into my mortall preparation:
and by midnight looke to heare further from me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: May I bee bold to acquaint his grace you are
gone about it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: I know not what the ſucceſſe wil be my Lord,
but the attempt I vow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: I know th’art valiant,
And to the poſſibility of thy ſouldierſhip,
Will ſubſcribe for thee: Farewell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par
SPEECH.LINE: I loue not many words. Exit

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.E.
SPEECH.LINE: No more then a fiſh loues water. Is not this
a ſtrange fellow my Lord, that ſo confidently ſeemes to
vndertake this buſineſſe, which he knowes is not to be
done, damnes himſelfe to do, & dares better be damnd
then to doo’t.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.G.
SPEECH.LINE: You do not know him my Lord as we dœ,
certaine it is that he will ſteale himſelfe into a mans fa-
uour, and for a weeke eſcape a great deale of diſcoue-
ries, but when you finde him out, you haue him euer af-
ter._

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Why do you thinke he will make no deede at
all of this that ſo ſeriouſlie hee doœs addreſſe himſelfe
vnto?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.E.
SPEECH.LINE: None in the world, but returne with an in-
uention, and clap vpon you two or three probable lies:
but we haue almoſt imboſt him, you ſhall ſee his fall to
night; for indeede he is not for your Lordſhippes re-
ſpeƈt. _

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.G.
SPEECH.LINE: Weele make you ſome ſport with the Foxe
ere we caſe him. He was firſt ſmoak’d by the old Lord
Lafew, when his diſguiſe and he is parted, tell me what
a ſprat you ſhall finde him, which you ſhall ſee this ve-
rie night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.E.
SPEECH.LINE: I muſt go looke my twigges,
He ſhall be caught.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Your brother he ſhall go along with me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.G.
SPEECH.LINE: As’t pleaſe your Lordſhip, Ile leaue you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Now wil I lead you to the houſe, and ſhew you
The Laſſe I ſpoke of.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.E.
SPEECH.LINE: But you ſay ſhe’s honeſt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: That’s all the fault: I ſpoke with hir but once,
And found her wondrous cold, but I ſent to her
By this ſame Coxcombe that we haue i’th winde
Tokens and Letters, which ſhe did reſend,
And this is all I haue done: She’s a faire creature,
Will you go ſee her?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.E
SPEECH.LINE: With all my heart my Lord. Exeunt

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: If you miſdoubt me that I am not ſhee,
I know not how I ſhall aſſure you further,
But I ſhall looſe the grounds I worke vpon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wid.
SPEECH.LINE: Though my eſtate be falne, I was well borne,
Nothing acquainted with theſe buſineſſes,
And would not put my reputation now
In any ſtaining aƈt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: Nor would I wiſh you.
Firſt giue me truſt, the Count he is my husband,
And what to your ſworne counſaile I haue ſpoken,
Is ſo from word to word: and then you cannot
By the good ayde that I of you ſhall borrow,
Erre in beſtowing it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wid.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſhould beleeue you,
For you haue ſhew’d me that which well approues
Y’are great in fortune.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: Take this purſe of Gold,
And let me buy your friendly helpe thus farre,
Which I will ouer-pay, and pay againe
When I haue found it. The Count he wœs your daughter,
Layes downe his wanton ſiedge before her beautie,
Reſolue to carrie her: let her in fine conſent
As wee’l direƈt her how ’tis best to beare it:
Now his important blood will naught denie,
That ſhee’l demand: a ring the Countie weares,
That downward hath ſucceeded in his houſe
From ſonne to ſonne, ſome foure or fiue diſcents,
Since the firſt father wore it. This Ring he holds
In moſt rich choice: yet in his idle fire,
To buy his will, it would not ſeeme too deere,
How ere repented after.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wid.
SPEECH.LINE: Now I ſee the bottome of your purpoſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: You ſee it lawfull then, it is no more,
But that your daughter ere ſhe ſeemes as wonne,
Deſires this Ring; appoints him an encounter;
In fine, deliuers me to fill the time,
Her ſelfe moſt chaſtly abſent: aﬅer
To marry her, Ile adde three thouſand Crownes
To what is paſt already.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wid.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue yeelded:
Inſtruƈt my daughter how ſhe ſhall perſeuer,
That time and place with this deceite ſo lawfull
May proue coherent. Euery night he comes
With Muſickes of all ſorts, and ſongs compos’d
To her vnworthineſſe: It nothing ſteeds vs
To chide him from our eeues, for he perſiſts
As if his life lay on’t.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: Why then to night
Let vs aſſay our plot, which if it ſpeed,
Is wicked meaning in a lawfull deede;
And lawfull meaning in a lawfull aƈt,
Where both not ſinne, and yet a ſinfull faƈt.
But let’s about it.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter one of the Frenchmen, with fiue or ſixe other ſouldiers in ambuſh

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lor.E.
SPEECH.LINE: He can come no other way but by this hedge
corner: when you ſallie vpon him, ſpeake what terrible
Language you will: though you vnderſtand it not your
ſelues, no matter: for we muſt not ſeeme to vnderſtand
him, vnleſſe ſome one among vs, whom wee muſt pro-
duce for an Interpreter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Sol.
SPEECH.LINE: Good Captaine, let me be th’ Interpreter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lor.E.
SPEECH.LINE: Art not acquainted with him? knowes he not
thy voice?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Sol.
SPEECH.LINE: No ſir I warrant you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lo.E.
SPEECH.LINE: But what linſie wolſy haſt thou to ſpeake to vs
againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Sol.
SPEECH.LINE: E’n ſuch as you ſpeake to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lo.E.
SPEECH.LINE: He muſt thinke vs ſome band of ſtrangers, i’th
aduerſaries entertainment. Now he hath a ſmacke of all
neighbouring Languages: therefore we muſt euery one
be a man of his owne fancie, not to know what we ſpeak
one to another: ſo we ſeeme to know, is to know ſtraight
our purpoſe: Choughs language, gabble enough, and
good enough. As for you interpreter, you muſt ſeeme
very politicke. But couch hoa, heere hee comes, to be-
guile two houres in a ſleepe, and then to returne & ſwear
the lies he forges.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Ten a clocke: Within theſe three houres ’twill
be time enough to gœ home. What ſhall I ſay I haue
done? It muſt bee a very plauſiue inuention that carries
it. They beginne to ſmoake mee, and diſgraces haue of
late, knock’d too oﬅen at my doore: I finde my tongue
is too foole-hardie, but my heart hath the feare of Mars
before it, and of his creatures, not daring the reports of
my tongue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lo.E.
SPEECH.LINE: This is the firſt truth that ere thine own tongue
was guiltie of.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: What the diuell ſhould moue mee to vndertake
the recouerie of this drumme, being not ignorant of the
impoſſibility, and knowing I had no ſuch purpoſe? I
muſt giue my ſelfe ſome hurts, and ſay I got them in ex-
ploit: yet ſlight ones will not carrie it. They will ſay,
came you off with ſo little? And great ones I dare not
giue, wherefore what’s the inſtance. Tongue, I muſt put
you into a Butter-womans mouth, and buy my ſelfe ano-
ther of Baiazeths Mule, if you prattle mee into theſe
perilles.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lo.E.
SPEECH.LINE: Is it poſſible he ſhould know what hee is, and
be that he is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: I would the cutting of my garments wold ſerue
the turne, or the breaking of my Spaniſh ſword.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lo.E.
SPEECH.LINE: We cannot affoord you ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Or the baring of my beard, and to ſay it was in
ſtratagem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lo.E.
SPEECH.LINE: ’Twould not do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Or to drowne my cloathes, and ſay I was ſtript.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lo.E.
SPEECH.LINE: Hardly ſerue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Though I ſwore I leapt from the window of the
Citadell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lo.E.
SPEECH.LINE: How deepe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Thirty fadome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lo.E.
SPEECH.LINE: Three great oathes would ſcarſe make that be
beleeued.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: I would I had any drumme of the enemies, I
would ſweare I recouer’d it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lo.E.
SPEECH.LINE: You ſhall heare one anon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: A drumme now of the enemies.

LINE.ITALIC: Throca movousus, cargo, cargo, cargo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All.
SPEECH.LINE: Cargo, cargo, cargo, villianda par corbo, cargo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: O ranſome, ranſome,
Do not hide mine eyes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Inter.
SPEECH.LINE: Boskos thromuldo boskos.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: I know you are the Muskos Regiment,
And I ſhall looſe my life for want of language.
If there be heere German or Dane, Low Dutch,
Italian, or French, let him ſpeake to me,
Ile diſcouer that, which ſhal vndo the Florentine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Int.
SPEECH.LINE: Boskos vauvado, I vnderſtand thee, & can ſpeake
thy tongue: Kerelybonto ſir, betake thee to thy faith, for
ſeuenteene ponyards are at thy boſome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Inter.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh pray, pray, pray,
Manka reuania dulche.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lo.E.
SPEECH.LINE: Oſcorbidulchos voliuorco.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Int.
SPEECH.LINE: The Generall is content to ſpare thee yet,
And hoodwinkt as thou art, will leade thee on
To gather from thee. Haply thou mayſt informe
Something to ſaue thy life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: O let me liue,
And all the ſecrets of our campe Ile ſhew,
Their force, their purpoſes: Nay, Ile ſpeake that,
Which you will wonder at.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Inter.
SPEECH.LINE: But wilt thou faithfully?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: If I do not, damne me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Inter.
SPEECH.LINE: Acordo linta.
Come on, thou are granted ſpace.Exit

SPEECH.SPEAKER: L.E.
SPEECH.LINE: Go tell the Count Roſſillion and my brother,
We haue caught the woodcocke, and will keepe him mufled
Till we do heare from them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sol.
SPEECH.LINE: Captaine I will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: L.E.
SPEECH.LINE: A will betray vs all vnto our ſelues,
Informe on that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sol.
SPEECH.LINE: So I will ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: L.E.
SPEECH.LINE: Till then Ile keepe him darke and ſafely lockt.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Bertram, and the Maide called Diana

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: They told me that your name was Fontybell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: No my good Lord, Diana.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Titled Goddeſſe,
And worth it with addition: but faire ſoule,
In your fine frame hath loue no qualitie?
If the quicke fire of youth light not your minde,
You are no Maiden but a monument
When you are dead you ſhould be ſuch a one
As you are now: for you are cold and ſterne,
And now you ſhould be as your mother was
When your ſweet ſelfe was got.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: She then was honeſt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: So ſhould you be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: No:
My mother did but dutie, ſuch (my Lord)
As you owe to your wife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: No more a’that:
I prethee do not ſtriue againſt my vowes:
I was compell’d to her, but I loue thee
By loues owne ſweet conſtraint, and will for euer
Do thee all rights of ſeruice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſo you ſerue vs
Till we ſerue you: But when you haue our Roſes,
You barely leaue our thornes to pricke our ſelues,
And mocke vs with our bareneſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: How haue I ſworne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: Tis not the many oathes that makes the truth,
But the plaine ſingle vow, that is vow’d true:
What is not holie, that we ſweare not by,
But take the high’st to witneſſe: then pray you tell me,
If I ſhould ſweare by Ioues great attributes,
I lou’d you deerely, would you beleeue my oathes,
When I did loue you ill? This ha’s no holding
To ſweare by him whom I proteſt to loue
That I will worke againſt him. Therefore your oathes
Are words and poore conditions, but vnſeal’d
At leſt in my opinion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Change it, change it:
Be not ſo holy cruell: Loue is holie,
And my integritie ne’re knew the crafts
That you do charge men with: Stand no more off,
But giue thy ſelfe vnto my ſicke deſires,
Who then recouers. Say thou art mine, and euer
My loue as it beginnes, ſhall ſo perſeuer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſee that men make rope’s in ſuch a ſcarre,
That wee’l forſake our ſelues. Giue me that Ring.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile lend it thee my deere; but haue no power
To giue it from me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: Will you not my Lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: It is an honour longing to our houſe,
Bequeathed downe from manie Anceſtors,
Which were the greateſt obloquie i’th world,
In me to looſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dian.
SPEECH.LINE: Mine Honors ſuch a Ring,
My chaſtities the Iewell of our houſe,
Bequeathed downe from many Anceſtors,
Which were the greateſt obloquie i’th world,
In mee to looſe. Thus your owne proper wiſedome
Brings in the Champion honor on my part,
Againſt your vaine aſſault.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere, take my Ring,
My houſe, mine honor, yea my life be thine,
And Ile be bid by thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: When midnight comes, knocke at my cham-
ber window:
Ile order take, my mother ſhall not heare.
Now will I charge you in the band of truth,
When you haue conquer’d my yet maiden-bed,
Remaine there but an houre, nor ſpeake to mee:
My reaſons are moſt ſtrong, and you ſhall know them,
When backe againe this Ring ſhall be deliuer’d:
And on your finger in the night, Ile put
Another Ring, that what in time proceeds,
May token to the future, our paſt deeds.
Adieu till then, then faile not: you haue wonne
A wife of me, though there my hope be done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: A heauen on earth I haue won by wooing thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Di.
SPEECH.LINE: For which, liue long to thank both heauen & me,
You may ſo in the end.
My mother told me iuſt how he would woo,
As if ſhe ſate in’s heart. She ſayes, all men
Haue the like oathes: He had ſworne to marrie me
When his wife’s dead: therfore Ile lye with him
When I am buried. Since Frenchmen are ſo braide,
Marry that will, I liue and die a Maid:
Onely in this diſguiſe, I think’t no ſinne,
To coſen him that would vniuſtly winne.Exit

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter the two French Captaines, and ſome two or three Souldiours

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.G.
SPEECH.LINE: You haue not giuen him his mothers letter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.E.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue deliu’red it an houre ſince, there is ſom
thing in’t that ſtings his nature: for on the reading it,
he chang’d almoſt into another man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.G.
SPEECH.LINE: He has much worthy blame laid vpon him,
for ſhaking off ſo good a wife, and ſo ſweet a Lady.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.E.
SPEECH.LINE: Eſpecially, hee hath incurred the euerlaſting
diſpleaſure of the King, who had euen tun’d his bounty
to ſing happineſſe to him. I will tell you a thing, but
you ſhall let it dwell darkly with you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.G.
SPEECH.LINE: When you haue ſpoken it ’tis dead, and I am
the graue of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.E.
SPEECH.LINE: Hee hath peruerted a young Gentlewoman
heere in Florence, of a moſt chaſte renown, & this night
he fleſhes his will in the ſpoyle of her honour: hee hath
giuen her his monumentall Ring, and thinkes himſelfe
made in the vnchaſte compoſition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.G.
SPEECH.LINE: Now God delay our rebellion as we are our
ſelues, what things are we.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.E.
SPEECH.LINE: Meerely our owne traitours. And as in the
common courſe of all treaſons, we ſtill ſee them reueale
themſelues, till they attaine to their abhorr’d ends: ſo
he that in this aƈtion contriues againſt his owne Nobi-
lity in his proper ſtreame, ore-flowes himſelfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.G.
SPEECH.LINE: Is it not meant damnable in vs, to be Trum-
peters of our vnlawfull intents? We ſhall not then haue
his company to night?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.E.
SPEECH.LINE: Not till after midnight: for hee is dieted to
his houre.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.G.
SPEECH.LINE: That approaches apace: I would gladly haue
him ſee his company anathomiz’d, that hee might take
a meaſure of his owne iudgements, wherein ſo curiouſly
he had ſet this counterfeit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.E.
SPEECH.LINE: We will not meddle with him till he come;
for his preſence muſt be the whip of the other.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.G.
SPEECH.LINE: In the meane time, what heare you of theſe
Warres?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.E.
SPEECH.LINE: I heare there is an ouerture of peace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.G.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, I aſſure you a peace concluded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.E.
SPEECH.LINE: What will Count Roſſillion do then? Will he
trauaile higher, or returne againe into France?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.G.
SPEECH.LINE: I perceiue by this demand, you are not alto-
gether of his councell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.E.
SPEECH.LINE: Let it be forbid ſir, ſo ſhould I bee a great
deale of his aƈt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.G.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, his wife ſome two months ſince fledde
from his houſe, her pretence is a pilgrimage to Saint Ia-
ques le grand; which holy vndertaking, with moſt au-
ſtere ſanƈtimonie ſhe accompliſht: and there reſiding,
the tenderneſſe of her Nature, became as a prey to her
greefe: in fine, made a groane of her laſt breath, & now
ſhe ſings in heauen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.E.
SPEECH.LINE: How is this iuſtiﬁed?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.G.
SPEECH.LINE: The ſtronger part of it by her owne Letters,
which makes her ſtorie true, euen to the poynt of her
death: her death it ſelfe, which could not be her ofﬁce
to ſay, is come: was faithfully confirm’d by the Reƈtor
of the place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.E.
SPEECH.LINE: Hath the Count all this intelligence?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.G.
SPEECH.LINE: I, and the particular confirmations, point
from point, to the full arming of the veritie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.E.
SPEECH.LINE: I am heartily ſorrie that hee’l bee gladde of
this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.G.
SPEECH.LINE: How mightily ſometimes, we make vs com-
forts of our loſſes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.E.
SPEECH.LINE: And how mightily ſome other times, wee
drowne our gaine in teares, the great dignitie that his
valour hath here acquir’d for him, ſhall at home be en-
countred with a ſhame as ample.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.G.
SPEECH.LINE: The webbe of our life, is of a mingled yarne,
good and ill together: our vertues would bee proud, if
our faults whipt them not, and our crimes would diſ-
paire if they were not cheriſh’d by our vertues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ser.
SPEECH.LINE: He met the Duke in the ſtreet ſir, of whom hee
hath taken a ſolemne leaue: his Lordſhippe will next
morning for France. The Duke hath offered him Let-
ters of commendations to the King.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.E.
SPEECH.LINE: They ſhall bee no more then needfull there,
if they were more then they can commend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: They cannot be too ſweete for the Kings tart-
neſſe, heere’s his Lordship now. How now my Lord,
i’ſt not after midnight?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue to night diſpatch’d ſixteene buſineſſes, a
moneths length a peece, by an abſtraƈt of ſucceſſe: I
haue congied with the Duke, done my adieu with his
neereſt; buried a wife, mourn’d for her, writ to my La-
die mother, I am returning, entertain’d my Conuoy, &
betweene these maine parcels of diſpatch, affeƈted ma-
ny nicer needs: the laſt was the greateſt, but that I haue
not ended yet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.E.
SPEECH.LINE: If the buſineſſe bee of any difficulty, and this
morning your departure hence, it requires haſt of your
Lordſhip.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: I meane the buſineſſe is not ended, as fearing
to heare of it hereafter: but ſhall we haue this dialogue
betweene the Foole and the Soldiour. Come, bring
forth this counterfet module, ha’s deceiu’d mee, like a
double-meaning Propheſier.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.E.
SPEECH.LINE: Bring him forth, ha’s ſate i’th ſtockes all night
poore gallant knaue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: No matter, his heeles haue deſeru’d it, in vſur-
ping his ſpurres ſo long. How dœs he carry himſelfe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.E.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue told your Lordſhip alreadie: The
ſtockes carrie him. But to anſwer you as you would be
vnderſtood, hee weepes like a wench that had ſhed her
milke, he hath confeſt himſelfe to Morgan, whom hee
ſuppoſes to be a Friar, fro[m] the time of his remembrance
to this very inſtant diſaſter of his ſetting i’th ſtockes:
and what thinke you he hath confeſt?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Nothing of me, ha’s a?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.E.
SPEECH.LINE: His confeſſion is taken, and it ſhall bee read
to his face, if your Lordſhippe be in’t, as I beleeue you
are, you muſt haue the patience to heare it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: A plague vpon him, muffeld; he can ſay nothing
of me: huſh, huſh.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.G.
SPEECH.LINE: Hoodman comes: Portotartaroſſa.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Inter.
SPEECH.LINE: He calles for the tortures, what will you ſay
without em.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: I will confeſſe what I know without conſtraint,
If ye pinch me like a Paſty, I can ſay no more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Int.
SPEECH.LINE: Bosko Chimurcho.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.
SPEECH.LINE: Boblibindo chicurmurco.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Int.
SPEECH.LINE: You are a mercifull Generall: Our Generall
bids you anſwer to what I ſhall aske you out of a Note.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: And truly, as I hope to liue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Int.
SPEECH.LINE: Firſt demand of him, how many horſe the Duke
is ſtrong. What ſay you to that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Fiue or ſixe thouſand, but very weake and vn-
ſeruiceable: the troopes are all ſcattered, and the Com-
manders verie poore rogues, vpon my reputation and
credit, and as I hope to liue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Int.
SPEECH.LINE: Shall I ſet downe your anſwer ſo?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Do, Ile take the Sacrament on’t, how & which
way you will: all’s one to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: What a paſt-ſauing ſlaue is this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.G.
SPEECH.LINE: Y’are deceiu’d my Lord, this is Mounſieur
Parrolles the gallant militariſt, that was his owne phraſe
that had the whole theoricke of warre in the knot of his
ſcarfe, and the praƈtiſe in the chape of his dagger.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.E.
SPEECH.LINE: I will neuer truſt a man againe, for keeping
his ſword cleane, nor beleeue he can haue euerie thing
in him, by wearing his apparrell neatly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Int.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, that’s ſet downe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Fiue or ſix thouſand horſe I ſed, I will ſay true,
or thereabouts ſet downe, for Ile ſpeake truth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.G.
SPEECH.LINE: He’s very neere the truth in this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: But I con him no thankes for’t in the nature he
deliuers it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Poore rogues, I pray you ſay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Int.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, that’s ſet downe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: I humbly thanke you ſir, a truth’s a truth, the
Rogues are maruailous poore.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Interp.
SPEECH.LINE: Demaund of him of what ſtrength they are a
foot. What ſay you to that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: By my troth ſir, if I were to liue this preſent
houre, I will tell true. Let me ſee, Spurio a hundred &
fiftie, Sebastian ſo many, Corambus ſo many,Iaques ſo
many: Guiltian, Cosmo, Lodowicke, and Gratij, two hun-
dred fiftie each: Mine owne Company, Chitopher, Vau-
mond, Bentij, two hundred fiftie each: ſo that the muſter
file, rotten and ſound, vppon my life amounts not to fif-
teene thouſand pole, halfe of the which, dare not ſhake
the ſnow from off their Caſſockes, leaſt they ſhake them-
ſelues to peeces.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſhall be done to him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.G.
SPEECH.LINE: Nothing, but let him haue thankes. Demand
of him my condition: and what credite I haue with the
Duke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Int.
SPEECH.LINE: Well that’s ſet downe: you ſhall demaund of
him, whether one Captaine Dumaine bee i’th Campe, a
Frenchman: what his reputation is with the Duke, what
his valour, honeſtie, and expertneſſe in warres: or whe-
ther he thinkes it were not poſſible with well-waighing
ſummes of gold to corrupt him to a reuolt. What ſay you
to this? What do you know of it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: I beſeech you let me anſwer to the particular of
the intergatories. Demand them ſingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Int.
SPEECH.LINE: Do you know this Captaine Dumaine?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: I know him, a was a Botchers Prentize in Paris,
from whence he was whipt for getting the Shrieues fool
with childe, a dumbe innocent that could not ſay him
nay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, by your leaue hold your hands, though I
know his braines are forfeite to the next tile that fals.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Int.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, is this Captaine in the Duke of Florences
campe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Vpon my knowledge he is, and lowſie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.G.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay looke not ſo vpon me: we ſhall heare of
your Lord anon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Int.
SPEECH.LINE: What is his reputation with the Duke?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: The Duke knowes him for no other, but a poore
Ofﬁcer of mine, and writ to mee this other day, to turne
him out a’th band. I thinke I haue his Letter in my poc-
ket. _

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Int.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry we’ll ſearch.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: In good ſadneſſe I do not know, either it is there,
or it is vpon a file with the Dukes other Letters, in my
Tent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Int.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere ’tis, heere’s a paper, ſhall I reade it to you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: I do not know if it be it or no.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Our Interpreter do’s it well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.G.
SPEECH.LINE: Excellently.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Int.
SPEECH.LINE: Dian, the Counts a foole, and full of gold.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: That is not the Dukes letter ſir: that is an ad-
uertiſement to a proper maide in Florence, one Diana, to
take heede of the allurement of one Count Roſſillion, a
fooliſh idle boy: but for all that very ruttiſh. I pray you
ſir put it vp againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Int.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, Ile reade it firſt by your fauour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: My meaning in’t I proteſt was very honeſt in the
behalfe of the maid: for I knew the young Count to be a
dangerous and laſciuious boy, who is a whale to Virgi-
nity, and deuours vp all the fry it finds.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Damnable both-ſides rogue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Int

LINE.ITALIC: When he ſweares oathes, bid him drop gold, and
take it:
Aﬅer he ſcores, he neuer payes the ſcore:
Halfe won is match well made, match and well make it,
He nere payes aﬅer-debts, take it before,
And ſay a ſouldier (Dian) told thee this:
Men are to mell with, boyes are not to kis.
For count of this, the Counts a Foole I know it,

SPEECH.LINE: Who payes before, but not when he dœs owe it.
Thine as he vow’d to thee in thine eare,
Parolles.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: He ſhall be whipt through the Armie with this
rime in’s forehead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.E.
SPEECH.LINE: This is your deuoted friend ſir, the manifold
Linguiſt, and the army-potent ſouldier.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: I could endure any thing before but a Cat, and
now he’s a Cat to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Int.
SPEECH.LINE: I perceiue ſir by your Generals lookes, wee ſhall
be faine to hang you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: My life ſir in any caſe: Not that I am afraide to
dye, but that my offences beeing many, I would repent
out the remainder of Nature. Let me liue ſir in a dunge-
on, i’th ſtockes, or any where, ſo I may liue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Int.
SPEECH.LINE: Wee’le ſee what may bee done, ſo you confeſſe
freely: therefore once more to this Captaine Dumaine:
you haue anſwer’d to his reputation with the Duke, and
to his valour. What is his honeſtie?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: He will ſteale ſir an Egge out of a Cloiſter: for
rapes and rauiſhments he paralels Neſſus. Hee profeſſes
not keeping of oaths, in breaking em he is ſtronger then
Hercules. He will lye ſir, with ſuch volubilitie, that you
would thinke truth were a foole: drunkenneſſe is his beſt
vertue, for he will be ſwine-drunke, and in his ſleepe he
does little harme, ſaue to his bed-cloathes about him:
but they know his conditions, and lay him in ſtraw. I
haue but little more to ſay ſir of his honeſty, he ha’s eue-
rie thing that an honeſt man ſhould not haue; what an
honeſt man ſhould haue, he has nothing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.G.
SPEECH.LINE: I begin to loue him for this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: For this deſcription of thine honeſtie? A pox
vpon him for me, he’s more and more a Cat.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Int.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſay you to his expertneſſe in warre?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Faith ſir, ha’s led the drumme before the Eng-
lish Tragedians: to belye him I will not, and more of his
ſouldierſhip I know not, except in that Country, he had
the honour to be the Ofﬁcer at a place there called Mile-
end, to inſtruƈt for the doubling of files. I would dœ the
man what honour I can, but of this I am not certaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.G.
SPEECH.LINE: He hath out-villain’d villanie ſo farre, that the
raritie redeemes him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: A pox on him, he’s a Cat ſtill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Int.
SPEECH.LINE: His qualities being at this poore price, I neede
not to aske you, if Gold will corrupt him to reuolt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, for a Cardceue he will ſell the fee-ſimple of
his ſaluation, the inheritance of it, and cut th’ intaile from
all remainders, and a perpetuall ſucceſſion for it perpe-
tually. _

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Int.
SPEECH.LINE: What’s his Brother, the other Captain Dumain?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.E.
SPEECH.LINE: Why do’s he aske him of me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Int.
SPEECH.LINE: What’s he?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: E’ne a Crow a’th ſame neſt: not altogether ſo
great as the firſt in goodneſſe, but greater a great deale in
euill. He excels his Brother for a coward, yet his Brother
is reputed one of the beſt that is. In a retreate hee out-
runnes any Lackey; marrie in comming on, hee ha’s the
Crampe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Int.
SPEECH.LINE: If your life be ſaued, will you vndertake to betray
the Florentine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: I, and the Captaine of his horſe, Count Roſſillion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Int.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile whiſper with the Generall, and knowe his
pleaſure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile no more drumming, a plague of all drummes,
onely to ſeeme to deſerue well, and to beguile the ſuppo-
ſition of that laſciuious yong boy the Count, haue I run
into this danger: yet who would haue ſuſpeƈted an am-
buſh where I was taken?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Int.
SPEECH.LINE: There is no remedy ſir, but you muſt dye: the
Generall ſayes, you that haue ſo traitorouſly diſcouerd
the ſecrets of your army, and made ſuch peſtifferous re-
ports of men very nobly held, can ſerue the world for
no honeſt vſe: therefore you muſt dye. Come headeſ-
man, off with his head.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: O Lord ſir let me liue, or let me ſee my death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Int.
SPEECH.LINE: That ſhall you, and take your leaue of all your
friends:_
So, looke about you, know you any heere?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Count.
SPEECH.LINE: Good morrow noble Captaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lo.E.
SPEECH.LINE: God bleſſe you Captaine Parolles.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.G.
SPEECH.LINE: God ſaue you noble Captaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lo.E.
SPEECH.LINE: Captain, what greeting will you to my Lord
Lafew? I am for France.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.G.
SPEECH.LINE: Good Captaine will you giue me a Copy of
the ſonnet you writ to Diana in behalfe of the Count
Roſſillion, and I were not a verie Coward, I’de compell
it of you, but far you well.Exeunt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Int.
SPEECH.LINE: You are vndone Captaine all but your ſcarfe,
that has a knot on’t yet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Who cannot be cruſh’d with a plot?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Inter.
SPEECH.LINE: If you could finde out a Countrie where but
women were that had receiued ſo much ſhame, you
might begin an impudent Nation. Fare yee well ſir, I
am for France too, we ſhall ſpeake of you there.Exit

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Yet am I thankfull: if my heart were great
’Twould burst at this: Captaine Ile be no more,
But I will eate, and drinke, and ſleepe as ſoft
As Captaine ſhall. Simply the thing I am
Shall make me liue: who knowes himſelfe a braggart
Let him feare this; for it will come to paſſe,
That euery braggart ſhall be found an Aſſe.
Ruſt ſword, coole bluſhes, and Parrolles liue
Safeſt in ſhame: being fool’d, by fool’rie thriue;
There’s place and meanes for euery man aliue.
Ile aﬅer them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: That you may well perceiue I haue not
wrong’d you,
One of the greateſt in the Chriſtian world
Shall be my ſuretie: for whoſe throne ’tis needfull
Ere I can perfeƈt mine intents, to kneele.
Time was, I did him a deſired office
Deere almoſt as his life, which gratitude
Through flintie Tartars bosome would peepe forth,
And anſwer thankes. I duly am inform’d,
His grace is at Marcellae, to which place
We haue conuenient conuoy: you muſt know
I am ſuppoſed dead, the Army breaking,
My husband hies him home, where heauen ayding,
And by the leaue of my good Lord the King,
Wee’l be before our welcome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wid.
SPEECH.LINE: Gentle Madam,
You neuer had a ſeruant to whoſe truſt
Your buſines was more welcome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: Nor your Miſtris
Euer a friend, whoſe thoughts more truly labour
To recompence your loue: Doubt not but heauen
Hath brought me vp to be your daughters dower,
As it hath fated her to be my motiue
And helper to a husband. But O ſtrange men,
That can ſuch ſweet vſe make of what they hate,
When ſawcie truſting of the coſin’d thoughts
Defiles the pitchy night, ſo luſt doth play
With what it loathes, for that which is away,
But more of this heereafter: you Diana,
Vnder my poore inſtructions yet muſt ſuffer
Something in my behalfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: Let death and honeſtie
Go with your impoſitions, I am yours
Vpon your will to ſuffer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: Yet I pray you:
But with the word the time will bring on ſummer,
When Briars ſhall haue leaues as well as thornes,
And be as ſweet as ſharpe: we muſt away,
Our Wagon is prepar’d, and time reuiues vs,
All's well that ends well, ſtill the fines the Crowne;
What ere the courſe, the end is the renowne. Exeunt

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Clowne, old Lady, and Lafew.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: No, no, no, your ſonne was miſled with a ſnipt
taffata fellow there, whoſe villanous ſaffron wold haue
made all the vnbak’d and dowy youth of a nation in his
colour: your daughter-in-law had beene aliue at this
houre, and your ſonne heere at home, more aduanc’d
by the King, then by that red-tail’d humble Bee I ſpeak
of._

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: I would I had not knowne him, it was the death
of the moſt vertuous gentlewoman, that euer Nature
had praiſe for creating. If ſhe had pertaken of my fleſh
and coſt mee the deereſt groanes of a mother, I could
not haue owed her a more rooted loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Twas a good Lady, ’twas a good Lady. Wee
may picke a thouſand ſallets ere wee light on ſuch ano-
ther hearbe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Indeed ſir ſhe was the ſweete Margerom of the
ſallet, or rather the hearbe of grace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: They are not hearbes you knaue, they are noſe-
hearbes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clowne.
SPEECH.LINE: I am no great Nabuchadnezar ſir, I haue not
much ſkill in grace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Whether dœſt thou profeſſe thy ſelfe, a knaue
or a foole?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: A foole ſir at a womans ſeruice, and a knaue at a
mans.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Your diſtinƈtion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: I would couſen the man of his wife, and do his
ſeruice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: So you were a knaue at his ſeruice indeed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: And I would giue his wife my bauble ſir to dœ
her ſeruice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: I will ſubſcribe for thee, thou art both knaue
and foole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: At your ſeruice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: No, no, no.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Why ſir, if I cannot ſerue you, I can ſerue as
great a prince as you are.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Whoſe that, a Frenchman?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Faith ſir a has an Engliſh maine, but his fiſno-
mie is more hotter in France then there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: What prince is that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: The blacke prince ſir, alias the prince of darke-
neſſe, alias the diuell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Hold thee there’s my purſe, I giue thee not this
to ſuggeſt thee from thy maſter thou talk’ſt off, ſerue
him ſtill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: I am a woodland fellow ſir, that alwaies loued
a great fire, and the maſter I ſpeak of euer keeps a good
fire, but ſure he is the Prince of the world, let his No-
bilitie remaine in’s Court. I am for the houſe with the
narrow gate, which I take to be too little for pompe to
enter: ſome that humble themſelues may, but the ma-
nie will be too chill and tender, and theyle bee for the
flowrie way that leads to the broad gate, and the great
fire.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Go thy waies, I begin to bee a wearie of thee,
and I tell thee ſo before, because I would not fall out
with thee. Go thy wayes, let my horſes be wel look’d
too, without any trickes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: If I put any trickes vpon em ſir, they ſhall bee
Iades trickes, which are their owne right by the law of
Nature.Exit

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: A ſhrewd knaue and an vnhappie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lady.
SPEECH.LINE: So a is. My Lord that’s gone made himſelfe
much ſport out of him, by his authoritie hee remaines
heere, which he thinkes is a pattent for his ſawcineſſe,
and indeede he has no pace, but runnes where he will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: I like him well, ‘tis not amiſſe: and I was about
to tell you, ſince I heard of the good Ladies death, and
that my Lord your ſonne was vpon his returne home. I
moued the King my master to ſpeake in the behalfe of
my daughter, which in the minoritie of them both, his
Maieſtie out of a ſelfe gracious remembrance did firſt
propoſe, his Highneſſe hath promiſ’d me to dœ it, and
to ſtoppe vp the diſpleaſure he hath conceiued againſt
your ſonne, there is no fitter matter. How do’s your
Ladyſhip like it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: With verie much content my Lord, and I wiſh
it happily effeƈted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: His Highneſſe comes poſt from Marcellus, of as
able bodie as when he number’d thirty, a will be heere
to morrow, or I am deceiu’d by him that in ſuch intel-
ligence hath ſeldome fail’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: It reioyces me, that I hope I ſhall ſee him ere I
die. I haue letters that my ſonne will be heere to night:
I ſhall beſeech your Lordſhip to remaine with mee, till
they meete together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, I was thinking with what manners I
might ſafely be admitted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lad.
SPEECH.LINE: You neede but pleade your honourable priui-
ledge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Ladie, of that I haue made a bold charter, but
I thanke my God, it holds yet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: O Madam, yonders my Lord your ſonne with
a patch of veluet on’s face, whether there bee a ſcar vn-
der’t or no, the Veluet knowes, but ‘tis a goodly patch
of Veluet, his left cheeke is a cheeke of two pile and a
halfe, but his right cheeke is worne bare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: A ſcarre nobly got,
Or a noble ſcarre, is a good liu’rie of honor,
So belike is that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: But it is your carbinado’d face.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Let vs go ſee
your ſonne I pray you, I long to talke
With the yong noble ſouldier.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clowne.
SPEECH.LINE: ’Faith there’s a dozen of em, with delicate
fine hats, and mo’t courteous feathers, which bow the
head, and nod at euerie man.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Hellen, Widdow, and Diana, with two Attendants

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: But this exceeding poſting day and night,
Muſt wear your ſpirits low, we cannot helpe it:
But ſince you haue made the daies and nights as one,
To weare your gentle limbes in my affayres,
Be bold you do ſo grow in my requitall,
As nothing can vnroote you. In happie time,
This man may helpe me to his Maieſties eare,
If he would ſpend his power. God ſaue you ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gent.
SPEECH.LINE: And you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, I haue ſeene you in the Court of France.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gent.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue beene ſometimes there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: I do preſume ſir, that you are not falne
From the report that gœs vpon your goodneſſe,
And therefore goaded with mo’t ſharpe occaſions,
Which lay nice manners by, I put you to
The vſe of your owne vertues, for the which
I ſhall continue thankefull.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gent.
SPEECH.LINE: What’s your will?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: That it will pleaſe you
To giue this poore petition to the King,
And ayde me with that ſtore of power you haue
To come into his preſence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gen.
SPEECH.LINE: The Kings not heere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: Not heere ſir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gen.
SPEECH.LINE: Not indeed,
He hence remou’d laſt night, and with more haſt
Then is his vſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wid.
SPEECH.LINE: Lord how we looſe our paines.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: All’s well that ends well yet,
Though time ſeeme ſo aduerſe, and meanes vnfit:
I do beſeech you, whither is he gone?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gent.
SPEECH.LINE: Marrie as I take it to Roſſillion,
Whither I am going.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: I do beſeech you ſir,
Since you are like to ſee the King before me,
Commend the paper to his gracious hand,
Which I preſume ſhall render you no blame,
But rather make you thanke your paines for it,
I will come aﬅer you with what good ſpeede
Our meanes will make vs meanes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gent.
SPEECH.LINE: This Ile do for you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: And you ſhall finde your ſelfe to be well thankt
what e’re falles more. We must to horſe againe, Go, go,
prouide.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Good Mr Lauatch giue my Lord Lafew this let-
ter, I haue ere now ſir beene better knowne to you, when
I haue held familiaritie with freſher cloathes: but I am
now ſir muddied in fortunes mood, and ſmell ſomewhat
ſtrong of her ſtrong diſpleaſure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Truely, Fortunes diſpleaſure is but ſluttiſh if it
ſmell ſo ſtrongly as thou ſpeak’st of: I will hencefoorth
eate no Fiſh of Fortunes butt’ring. Prethee alow the
winde.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay you neede not to ſtop your noſe ſir: I ſpake
but by a Metaphor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Indeed ſir, if your Metaphor ſtinke, I will ſtop
my noſe, or againſt any mans Metaphor. Prethe get thee
further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray you ſir deliuer me this paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Foh, prethee ſtand away: a paper from fortunes
cloſe-ſtoole, to giue to a Nobleman. Looke heere he
comes himſelfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere is a purre of Fortunes ſir, or of Fortunes
Cat, but not a Muſcat, that ha’s falne into the vncleane
fiſh-pond of her diſpleaſure, and as he ſayes is muddied
withall. Pray you ſir, vse the Carpe as you may, for he
lookes like a poore decayed, ingenious, fooliſh, raſcally
knaue. I dœ pittie his diſtreſſe in my ſmiles of comfort,
and leaue him to your Lordſhip.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord I am a man whom fortune hath cruel-
ly ſcratch’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: And what would you haue me to dœ? ’Tis too
late to paire her nailes now. Wherein haue you played
the knaue with fortune that ſhe ſhould ſcratch you, who
of her ſelfe is a good Lady, and would not haue knaues
thriue long vnder? There’s a Cardecue for you: Let the
Iuſtices make you and fortune friends; I am for other
buſineſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: I beſeech your honour to heare mee one ſingle
word,

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: you begge a ſingle peny more: Come you ſhall
ha’t, ſaue your word.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: My name my good Lord is Parrolles.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: You begge more then word then. Cox my paſ-
ſion, giue me your hand: How dœs your drumme?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: O my good Lord, you were the firſt that found
mee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Was I inſooth? And I was the firſt that loſt thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: It lies in you my Lord to bring me in ſome grace
for you did bring me out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Out vpon thee knaue, dœſt thou put vpon mee
at once both the ofﬁce of God and the diuel: one brings
thee in grace, and the other brings thee out. The Kings
comming I know by his Trumpets. Sirrah, inquire fur-
ther aﬅer me, I had talke of you laſt night, though you
are a foole and a knaue, you ſhall eate, go too, follow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: I praiſe God for you.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Flouriſh. Enter King, old Lady, Lafew, the two French Lords, with attendants

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: We loſt a Iewell of her, and our eſteeme
Was made much poorer by it: but your ſonne,
As mad in folly, lack’d the ſence to know
Her eſtimation home.
Old La.
’Tis paſt my Liege,
And I beſeech your Maieſtie to make it
Naturall rebellion, done i’th blade of youth,
When oyle and fire, too ſtrong for reaſons force,
Ore-beares it, and burnes on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: My honour’d Lady,
I haue forgiuen and forgotten all,
Though my reuenges were high bent vpon him,
And watch’d the time to ſhoote.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: This I muſt ſay,
But firſt I begge my pardon: the yong Lord
Did to his Maieſty, his Mother, and his Ladie,
Offence of mighty note; but to himſelfe
The greateſt wrong of all. He loſt a wife,
Whose beauty did aſtoniſh the ſuruey
Of richeſt eies: whoſe words all eares tooke captiue,
Whose deere perfeƈtion, hearts that ſcorn’d to ſerue,
Humbly call’d Miſtris.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Praiſing what is loſt,
Makes the remembrance deere. Well, call him hither,
We are reconcil’d, and the firſt view ſhall kill
All repetition: Let him not aske our pardon,
The nature of his great offence is dead,
And deeper then obliuion, we do burie
Th’ incensing reliques of it. Let him approach
A ſtranger, no offender; and informe him
So ’tis our will he ſhould.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gent.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſhall my Liege.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſayes he to your daughter,
Haue you ſpoke?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: All that he is, hath reference to your Highnes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Then ſhall we haue a match. I haue letters ſent
me, that ſets him high in fame.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: He lookes well on’t.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: I am not a day of ſeaſon,
For thou maiſt ſee a ſun-ſhine, and a haile
In me at once: But to the brighteſt beames
Diſtraƈted clouds giue way, ſo ſtand thou forth,
The time is faire againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: My high repented blames
Deere Soueraigne pardon to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: All is whole,
Not one word more of the conſumed time,
Let’s take the inſtant by the forward top:
For we are old, and on our quick’ſt decrees
Th’ inaudible, and noiſeleſſe foot of time
Steales, ere we can effect them. You remember
The daughter of this Lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Admiringly my Liege, at firſt
I ſtucke my choice vpon her, ere my heart
Durſt make too bold a herauld of my tongue:
Where the impreſſion of mine eye enfixing,
Contempt his ſcornfull Perſpectiue did lend me,
Which warpt the line, of euerie other fauour,
Scorn’d a faire colour, or expreſt it ſtolne,
Extended or contraƈted all proportions
To a mo’t hideous obieƈt. Thence it came,
That ſhe whom all men praiſ’d, and whom my ſelfe,
Since I haue loſt, haue lou’d; was in mine eye
The duſt that did offend it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Well excuſ’d:
That thou didſt loue her, ſtrikes ſome ſcores away
From the great compt: but loue that comes too late,
Like a remorſefull pardon ſlowly carried
To the great ſender, turnes a ſowre offence,
Crying, that’s good that’s gone: Our raſh faults,
Make triuiall price of ſerious things we haue,
Not knowing them, vntill we know their graue.
Oﬅ our diſpleaſures to our ſelues vniust,
Deſtroy our friends, and after weepe their duſt:
Our owne loue waking, cries to ſee what’s done,
While ſhamefull hate ſleepes out the aﬅernoone.
Be this ſweet Helens knell, and now forget her.
Send forth your amorous token for faire Maudlin,
The maine conſents are had, and heere wee’l ſtay
To ſee our widdowers ſecond marriage day:
Which better then the firſt, O deere heauen bleſſe,
Or, ere they meete in me, O Nature ceſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Come on my ſonne, in whom my houſes name
Muſt be digeſted: giue a fauour from you
To ſparkle in the ſpirits of my daughter,
That ſhe may quickly come. By my old beard,
And eu’rie haire that’s on’t, Helen that’s dead
Was a ſweet creature: ſuch a ring as this,
The last that ere I tooke her leaue at Court,
I ſaw vpon her finger.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Hers it was not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Now pray you let me ſee it. For mine eye,
While I was ſpeaking, oﬅ was fasten’d too’t:
This Ring was mine, and when I gaue it Hellen,
I bad her if her fortunes euer ſtoode
Neceſſitied to helpe, that by this token
I would releeue her. Had you that craft to reaue her
Of what ſhould ſtead her moſt?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: My gracious Soueraigne,
How ere it pleaſes you to take it ſo,
The ring was neuer hers.
Old La.
Sonne, on my life
I haue ſeene her weare it, and ſhe reckon’d it
At her liues rate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: I am ſure I ſaw her weare it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: You are deceiu’d my Lord, ſhe neuer ſaw it:
In Florence was it from a caſement throwne mee,
Wrap’d in a paper, which contain’d the name
Of her that threw it: Noble ſhe was, and thought
I ſtood ingag’d, but when I had ſubſcrib’d
To mine owne fortune, and inform’d her fully,
I could not anſwer in that courſe of Honour
As ſhe had made the ouerture, ſhe ceaſt
In heauie ſatiſfaƈtion, and would neuer
Receiue the Ring againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Platus himſelfe,
That knowes the tinƈt and multiplying med’cine,
Hath not in natures myſterie more ſcience,
Then I haue in this Ring. ’Twas mine, ’twas Helens,
Who euer gaue it you: then if you know
That you are well acquainted with your ſelfe,
Confeſſe ’twas hers, and by what rough enforcement
You got it from her. She call’d the Saints to ſuretie,
That ſhe would neuer put it from her finger,
Vnleſſe ſhe gaue it to your ſelfe in bed,
Where you haue neuer come: or ſent it vs
Vpon her great diſaſter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: She neuer ſaw it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou ſpeak’ſt it falſely: as I loue mine Honor,
And mak’ſt connecturall feares to come into me,
Which I would faine ſhut out, if it ſhould proue
That thou art ſo inhumane, ’twill not proue ſo:
And yet I know not, thou didst hate her deadly,
And ſhe is dead, which nothing but to cloſe
Her eyes my ſelfe, could win me to beleeue,
More then to ſee this Ring. Take him away,
My fore-paſt proofes, how ere the matter fall
Shall taze my feares of little vanitie,
Hauing vainly fear’d too little. Away with him,
Wee’l ſiﬅ this matter further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: If you ſhall proue
This Ring was euer hers, you ſhall as eaſie
Proue that I husbanded her bed in Florence,
Where yet ſhe neuer was.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: I am wrap’d in diſmall thinkings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gen.
SPEECH.LINE: Gracious Soueraigne.
Whether I haue beene too blame or no, I know not,
Here’s a petition from a Florentine,
Who hath for foure or fiue remoues come ſhort,
To tender it her ſelfe. I vndertooke it,
Vanquiſh’d thereto by the faire grace and ſpeech
Of the poore ſuppliant, who by this I know
Is heere attending: her busineſſe lookes in her
With an importing viſage, and ſhe told me
In a ſweet verball breefe, it did concerne
Your Highneſſe with her ſelfe.

LINE.ITALIC: Vpon his many proteſtations to marrie mee when his wife was

SPEECH.LINE: dead, I bluſh to ſay it, he wonne me. Now is the Count Roſ-

LINE.ITALIC: ſillion a Widdower, his vowes are forfeited to mee, and my
honors payed to him. Hee ſtole from Florence, taking no
leaue, and I follow him to his Countrey for Iuſtice: Grant
it me, O King, in you it beſt lies, otherwiſe a ſeducer ﬂou-
riſhes, and a poore Maid is vndone.

SPEECH.LINE: Diana Capilet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: I will buy me a ſonne in Law in a faire, and toule
for this. Ile none of him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: The heauens haue thought well on thee Lafew,
To bring forth this discou’rie, ſeeke theſe ſutors:
Go ſpeedily, and bring againe the Count.
I am a-feard the life of Hellen (Ladie)
Was fowly ſnatcht.
Old La.
Now iuſtice on the dœrs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: I wonder ſir, ſir, wiues are monſters to you,
And that you flye them as you ſweare them Lordſhip,
Yet you deſire to marry. What woman’s that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: I am my Lord a wretched Florentine,
Deriued from the ancient Capilet,
My ſuite as I do vnderſtand you know,
And therefore know how farre I may be pittied.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wid.
SPEECH.LINE: I am her Mother ſir, whoſe age and honour
Both ſuffer vnder this complaint we bring,
And both ſhall ceaſe, without your remedie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Come hether Count, do you know theſe Wo-
men?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, I neither can nor will denie,
But that I know them, do they charge me further?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: Why do you looke ſo ſtrange vpon your wife?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: She’s none of mine my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: If you ſhall marrie
You giue away this hand, and that is mine,
You giue away heauens vowes, and thoſe are mine:
You giue away my ſelfe, which is knowne mine:
For I by vow am ſo embodied yours,
That ſhe which marries you, muſt marrie me,
Either both or none.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Your reputation comes too ſhort for my daugh-
ter, you are no husband for her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, this is a fond and deſp’rate creature,
Whom ſometime I haue laugh’d with: Let your highnes
Lay a more noble thought vpon mine honour,
Then for to thinke that I would ſinke it heere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir for my thoughts, you haue them il to friend,
Till your deeds gaine them fairer: proue your honor,
Then in my thought it lies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dian.
SPEECH.LINE: Good my Lord,
Aske him vpon his oath, if hee do’s thinke
He had not my virginity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſaiſt thou to her?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: She’s impudent my Lord,
And was a common gameſter to the Campe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: He do’s me wrong my Lord: If I were ſo,
He might haue bought me at a common price.
Do not beleeue him. O behold this Ring,
Whoſe high reſpect and rich validitie
Did lacke a Paralell: yet for all that
He gaue it to a Commoner a’th Campe
If I be one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coun.
SPEECH.LINE: He bluſhes, and ’tis hit:
Of ſixe preceding Anceſtors that Iemme
Confer’d by teſtament to’th ſequent iſſue
Hath it beene owed and worne. This is his wife,
That Ring’s a thouſand proofes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Me thought you ſaide
You ſaw one heere in Court could witneſſe it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: I did my Lord, but loath am to produce
So bad an inſtrument, his names Parrolles.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſaw the man to day, if man he bee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Finde him, and bring him hether.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: What of him:
He’s quoted for a moſt perfidious ſlaue
With all the ſpots a’th world, taxt and deboſh’d,
Whoſe nature ſickens: but to ſpeake a truth,
Am I, or that or this for what he’l vtter,
That will ſpeake any thing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: She hath that Ring of yours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſ.
SPEECH.LINE: I thinke ſhe has; certaine it is I lyk’d her,
And boorded her i’th wanton way of youth:
She knew her di’tance, and did angle for mee,
Madding my eagerneſſe with her re’traint,
As all impediments in fancies cour’e
Are motiues of more fancie, and in fine,
Her in’uite comming with her moderne grace,
Subdu’d me to her rate, ſhe got the Ring,
And I had that which any inferiour might
At Market price haue bought.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: I muſt be patient:
You that haue turn’d off a first ſo noble wife,
May iuſtly dyet me. I pray you yet,
(Since you lacke vertue, I will looſe a husband)
Send for your Ring, I will returne it home,
And giue me mine againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ros.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue it not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: What Ring was yours I pray you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dian.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir much like the ſame vpon your finger.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Know you this Ring, this Ring was his of late.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: And this was it I gaue him being a bed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: The ſtory then gœs falſe, you threw it him
Out of a Caſement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia
SPEECH.LINE: I haue ſpoke the truth. Enter Parolles.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ros.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, I do confeſſe the ring was hers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: You boggle ſhrewdly, euery feather ſtarts you:
Is this the man you ſpeake of?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: I, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Tell me ſirrah, but tell me true I charge you,
Not fearing the diſpleaſure of your maſter:
Which on your iuſt proceeding, Ile keepe off,
By him and by this woman heere, what know you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: So pleaſe your Maieſty, my maſter hath bin an
honourable Gentleman. Trickes hee hath had in him,
which Gentlemen haue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come, to’th’ purpoſe: Did hee loue this
woman?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Faith ſir he did loue her, but how.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: How I pray you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: He did loue her ſir, as a Gent. loues a Woman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: How is that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: He lou’d her ſir, and lou’d her not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: As thou art a knaue and no knaue, what an equi-
uocall Companion is this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: I am a poore man, and at your Maieſties com-
mand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Hee’s a good drumme my Lord, but a naughtie
Orator.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dian.
SPEECH.LINE: Do you know he promiſt me marriage?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Faith I know more then Ile ſpeake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: But wilt thou not ſpeake all thou know’ſt?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Par.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes ſo pleaſe your Maieſty: I did gœ betweene
them as I ſaid, but more then that he loued her, for in-
deede he was madde for her, and talkt of Sathan, and of
Limbo, and of Furies, and I know not what: yet I was in
that credit with them at that time, that I knewe of their
going to bed, and of other motions, as promiſing her
marriage, and things which would deriue mee ill will to
ſpeake of, therefore I will not ſpeake what I know.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou haſt ſpoken all alreadie, vnleſſe thou canſt
ſay they are maried, but thou art too fine in thy euidence,
therefore ſtand aſide. This Ring you ſay was yours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: I my good Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Where did you buy it? Or who gaue it you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: It was not giuen me, nor I did not buy it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Who lent it you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: It was not lent me neither.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Where did you finde it then?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: I found it not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: If it were yours by none of all these wayes,
How could you giue it him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: I neuer gaue it him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: This womans an eaſie gloue my Lord, ſhe gœs
off and on at pleaſure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: This Ring was mine, I gaue it his firſt wife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: It might be yours or hers for ought I know.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Take her away, I do not like her now,
To priſon with her: and away with him,
Vnleſſe thou telſt me where thou hadſt this Ring,
Thou dieſt within this houre.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile neuer tell you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Take her away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile put in baile my liedge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: I thinke thee now ſome common Cuſtomer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: By Ioue if euer I knew man ’twas you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Wherefore haſt thou accuſde him al this while.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: Because he’s guiltie, and he is not guilty:
He knowes I am no Maid, and hee’l ſweare too’t:
Ile ſweare I am a Maid, and he knowes not.
Great King I am no ſtrumpet, by my life,
I am either Maid, or else this old mans wife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: She dœs abuſe our eares, to priſon with her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dia.
SPEECH.LINE: Good mother fetch my bayle. Stay Royall ſir,
The Ieweller that owes the Ring is ſent for,
And he ſhall ſurety me. But for this Lord,
Who hath abuſ’d me as he knowes himſelfe,
Though yet he neuer harm’d me, heere I quit him.
He knowes himſelfe my bed he hath defil’d,
And at that time he got his wife with childe:
Dead though ſhe be, ſhe feeles her yong one kicke:
So there’s my riddle, one that’s dead is quicke,
And now behold the meaning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Is there no exorciſt
Beguiles the truer Ofﬁce of mine eyes?
Is’t reall that I ſee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: No my good Lord,
’Tis but the ſhadow of a wife you ſee,
The name, and not the thing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ros.
SPEECH.LINE: Both, both, O pardon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh my good Lord, when I was like this Maid,
I found you wondrous kinde, there is your Ring,
And looke you, heeres your letter: this it ſayes,
When from my ﬁnger you can get this Ring,
And is by me with childe, &c. This is done,
Will you be mine now you are doubly wonne?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ros.
SPEECH.LINE: If ſhe my Liege can make me know this clearly,
Ile loue her dearely, euer, euer dearly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: If it appeare not plaine, and proue vntrue,
Deadly diuorce ſtep betweene me and you.
O my deere mother do I ſee you liuing?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laf.
SPEECH.LINE: Mine eyes ſmell Onions, I ſhall weepe anon:
Good Tom Drumme lend me a handkercher.
So I thanke thee, waite on me home, Ile make ſport with
thee: Let thy curtſies alone, they are ſcuruy ones.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Let vs from point to point this ſtorie know,
To make the euen truth in pleaſure ﬂow:
If thou beeſt yet a freſh vncropped ﬂower,
Chooſe thou thy husband, and Ile pay thy dower.
For I can gueſſe, that by thy honeſt ayde,
Thou keptſt a wife her ſelfe, thy ſelfe a Maide.
Of that and all the progreſſe more and leſſe,
Reſoluedly more leaſure ſhall expreſſe:
All yet ſeemes well, and if it end ſo meete,
The bitter paſt, more welcome is the ſweet.

LINE.ITALIC: The Kings a Begger, now the Play is done,
All is well ended, if this ſuite be wonne,
That you expreſſe Content: which we will pay,
With ſtrife to pleaſe you, day exceeding day:
Ours be your patience then, and yours our parts,
Your gentle hands lend vs, and take our hearts.
